shadows to aid the Nemesis. The goal of the game is to defeat all Nemesis and protect the realm. There are 2 ways to play
the game: semi-co-op or fully-co-op/solo with the hidden agendas removed.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Push Your Luck, Race, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Mallorca Express
description:
Description from the designer:

A print & play board game (using components from Finca) for 2-6 players.

In Mallorca Express each player represents a Majorcan farmer growing fruits and trying to sell them for as much profit as possible.

Regarding game mechanics, Mallorca Express is influenced by games like Alien Frontiers and Troyes and their use of dice for worker placement.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Naturally Disastrous: Discoverable Items Promo Pack
description:
This promo pack was available during Kickstarter.com campaigns and at conventions. It contains the following:

Cloaking Device- The owner of the device cannot be seen by natives unless they are the only Alien not KO'd or Mutated. If the Yellow Alien is in play, and all other Aliens are KO'd or Mutated, the cloaking device has no effect.

M.R.E. (Microwavable Ready Earth-food)- The Medical officer of the crew figured out that if you Microwave a lemon filled doughnut allows you to heal all your wounds. It is then discarded.

Malfunctioning Transporter- This functions similarly to a transporter but you have to roll the D10 and D8 die to decide where you end up. You can also discard it to move a Native or Mutated Alien instead of an Alien.

name: Hull Breach!: Xeros Orbital Shipyards
description:
Originally released as part of Hull Breach!'s Corporate Wars box set, this individual deck has been revamped and improved for the current edition of the game.

Commander, nobody can compete with the industrial might that stands behind you. Xeros Engineering produces ships and heavy weapons better than anybody else can – we expect you to leverage this production to further the company's aims. Most of your enemies will have difficulties supplying and maintaining battle groups with heavy combatants out on the frontier, so put your trust in the captains of your heavy-hitters. They and their Marines won't let you down.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck

name: Native Wars
description:
Description from the publisher:

Native Wars is a competitive, two-player card game, where players manage their tribe decks to capture the most territories.

This game features unique card and dice play. Players' cards are numbered in which you have to roll two dice to activate them by the total sum of your roll. Their card effects guide your tactical actions in the game through manipulating cards in play, attacking the enemy, or granting war power.

Players will need to recruit the best tribe members by collecting copper and paying for their costs. You then need to decide which tribe members will go into certain territories to take on your opponent's tribe. Be the first team to capture two out of the five territories to win the game!
categories: American Indian Wars, Card Game, Dice
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Lemmings
description:
Keep your Lemmings on the board whilst trying to push your opponents over the cliff.
The order in which the Lemmings move is dictated by the lemmings cards, one for each Lemming. These are shuffled and turned over one at a time. The player chooses where his Lemming is to enter the board and then Lemmings are moved forward 4 spaces unless they hit another Lemming which then moves forward for the remaining parts of the 4 hex move. If the nudged Lemming hits another Lemming, then that one carries on the move. lemmings can be bounced off the cliff wall and back onto the track. Also players have cards which can cause a Mad lemming Dash which can effect other Lemmings. First Lemming over the cliff scores 1 point, the second scores 2, and so on up to 15 points for the last. It is recommended that players play 3 or more rounds and add the scores.

name: Dungeon Mountain
description:
Description from the publisher:

Dungeon Mountain is a tabletop dungeon crawler for two players.

It is published as a play book, containing the rules, a space for custom rules and over 50 game boards.

A free, printable game board template and pocket rule book is also available.

The object of the game is to escape the other player's dungeon.
Each player creates a dungeon on an 8x8 grid. This contains a starting point and exit point. A class system can be used to predict the difficulty of a dungeon allowing for fair play or else to create a handicap for games between players of different experience.

Players place several items throughout the dungeon. These are Big Monsters, Small Monsters, Traps, Hammers and Gems. The position of these items does not change during gameplay.

Combat with Monsters is decided with attack points that are assigned when the monsters are placed.

On a second blank grid the players are given the starting coordinates. Players then navigate their opponents dungeon by calling out directions. Players continue their turn until they attempt a move into a wall or certain items. As they progress the players mark their progress on the grids.

The winner is the first player to exit the dungeon.
Number of lives used, monsters defeated and items collected can also be counted as points.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Line Drawing, Network and Route Building, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Worker Placement

name: Temple of the Sun God
description:
Description from the designer:

An abstract game for 2 players. Players decide to either act as the Spirit of the Sun God or as Noble Explorers mistaken for Grave Robbers. While the Explorers work to find each other, the Spirit works to bring down the temple upon them.

Each turn consists of the two players selecting a certain number of spirit stones in secret. After the selection is complete the combined number of spirit stones of the two players determines the action for the turn.

The goal of the game is to escape if you are the Explorers, or stop the escape if you are the Spirits.

name: Sicaliptic: the erotic card game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Sicaliptic is an erotic game for two players. (+18)

During the game the players propose each other a combination of an action and a body part from the cards of their hand.

Then, players thow the die. Depending on the number obtained, the player who chose even or odd numbers previously, wins.

The winner throws the die again and the number obtained will be the number of times (or seconds) that the other player must do the action proposed.

The winner will add a point in his own score indicator.

Each player will level up as they win rounds, and the exposed body parts will become more intimate as they do so.

The game will end when one of the players arrives to the end of the score indicator and the loser one becomes completely naked.

name: Chez Geek: TableTalk Promo Card
description:
A promo Activity card for Chez Geek, featuring the web-series TableTop hosted by Wil Wheaton.

Description of the card:

- Activity (TV)
- Slack 1
- Cost 0

"This week on TableTalk, we play a board game and I get pwned! Like always!"

Description of the game:

In this light, humorous, and fast-paced card game that parodies geek culture and co-habitation, players are roommates just trying to get through life with as little work as possible.

At setup each player is dealt a Job card which lists their free time, income, a special ability that they possess and their Slack goal. Players are also dealt five Life cards. The space directly in front of a player is their Room, where cards will be played during the course of the game. Slack can be represented using any available chit or counter, but every player begins with a Slack total of zero.

name: D-Day Express: Saving Private Ryan
description:
Normandy, June 9, 1944. You have survived the brutal invasion of Omaha Beach, but your mission is not complete. You have been given new high-priority orders from General George C. Marshall to locate a missing paratrooper, Private First Class James Francis Ryan, and bring him home to safety.

Private Ryan’s whereabouts are unknown. Rumors place him directly in the middle of enemy-occupied territory laden with snipers, minefields, deadly tanks, and heavily fortified villages.

You have been made Captain and placed in charge of this mission. With limited intel and an even smaller chance of success, you gather a team, ready your equipment, and set off to bring Private Ryan home.

'D-Day Express: Saving Private Ryan' is a solo wargame played using a single deck of double-sided cards. There are no counters and no record-keeping is needed to play. Cards are used to represent terrain, enemies, friendly units, damage, mines, debris, and hills, as well as used to generate random events, direct enemy fire, manage close combat engagements, and even determine whether snipers are successful in hitting their targets.

'D-Day Express: Saving Private Ryan' is a portable, compelling wargame experience that is easy to set up, quick to take down, perfect for travel and gaming in tight spaces, and most importantly, is fun to play! Just shuffle the cards and play!
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven

name: Sprinto
description:
The new game adventure of the Miki the Moth.
Straight from the Filobiblonia, the lend of books and games lovers. SPRINTO - is the favorite board game of bookworms, Grace and aunt Zgryzelda. "The day without Sprinto play with a cup of rose tea, is a lost day" - according to the Miki the Moth.
Let's try to play in the really loony board game, invite your freinds and family. As soon as possible move pawns on yours route to the end. Do you think, it's easy? No way!
You can lose all your pawns and give them back to the beginning or... with frozen pawns idly watch how the other wins!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement

name: The Glass Peak
description:
The Glass Peak is a party game that draws from inclusive ideas that the authors appreciated in games. The main idea is simple: roll a die, pick up a card, perform the task. First player to reach the last square on the board wins. The Volcano Cup and your own friend's shenanigans will make this a night to remember!

While the game is a party game and does encourage folks to indulge it prioritizes having a good time over anything else.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Dust Tactics: Gunnery Sergeant Q 'Mack' MacDonald â "Machette Mack"
description: Gunnery Sergeant Q 'Mack' MacDonald has been with the United States Marine Corps for more than ten years now. Twice its boxing champion, 'Mack' has unsurpassed martial skills that he puts to good use against all enemies of the Allies, mostly Japanese in the Pacific.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: USMC Demolition Squads â "The Saints"
description:
When the Imperial Japanese Navy advanced through the Pacific, it conquered a vast number of remote islands. Ordered to defend them were a few resolute soldiers who didn’t have much equipment, but had a lot of free time on their hands. So they did as any soldier in the world does when there’s nothing else to do: they dug in.

When the reconquest of the Pacific started, the United States Marine Corps had to deal with fortified positions right away. Some small islands had more bunkers and pillboxes than they had coconut trees! It was quickly pretty obvious that the Corps would need to adapt to get the job done.

The Marines were not prepared for this, as not everyone could carry a flame-thrower, therefore they needed something more practical. The Corps found its solution with the creation of the Demolition Squads. These men would be given basic instructions on how to handle explosives: throw a satchel full of them in roughly the right direction, and run the other way as fast as possible.

It was soon evident that if you were sent into one of these squads, you were soon to meet your maker - whatever you conceived Him to be. With such a high rate of casualties, they called themselves ‘The Saints’. Nevertheless, these Marines are immensely respected in the Corps, and often benefit from slightly more relaxed standards of discipline.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: USMC Assault Squad â "Hell Blazers"
description: Armed with a variety of powerful short range weapons, these Marines are among the most feared in the Pacific. Their Flamethrowers can blow up anything from the heaviest walker to the bulkiest bunker.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: USMC Rifle Squad â "Mavericks"
description: There aren't many soldiers on the planet brave enough to face five men armed with Browning Automatic Rifles, or they have a serious death wish. The staple of the Marine Corps is this squad, which can be found in numbers wherever the USMC fights.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Subterranean Cities
description: Subterranean Cities is played in four rounds, during which players will take turns placing one of their three crew members in their ship to add and activate ship part tiles. These parts are used to maneuver the ship and collect more parts. Victory points are earned by building your ship, and refurbishing ship parts into structures. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the final round is the winner.

name: Dust Tactics: USMC Heavy Engineer Squad â "Steel Marines"
description: Combat engineers and pioneers always have the most dangerous post in an army: always on the first line at the front. Clearing a path through minefields and barbed wire for the rest of the army to advance is no small feat, and these guys need every advantage they can get. In the most dangerous terrain, the USMC calls on the Heavy Engineers. With their Ground Assault Power Armour they carry weapons no ordinary man could.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: M1D Light Assault Walker Anti-tank â "Bushmaster"
description: The Marines love lightning speed attacks and outflank maneuvers. And heavy firepower as well... There aren't many vehicles on the planet that match these three elements as well as the Bushmaster. Based on the already famous Light Assault Walker chassis, this new machine is widely used by the Corps, and soon by the grand Allied Army.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: M3A2 Medium Combat Walker "Mickey (Light)"
description: This variant of the original Mickey, dubbed the ‘Light Mickey’ by the Marines, was created specifically for the United States Marine Corps. Its open-topped turret makes it much more comfortable to operate in some of the environments that these guys fight in. As with Allied troops across the planet, the Marines love this machine. It’s resilient, easy to operate, and packs a lot of punch. Since its entry into service with the USMC, the Light Mickey has been adopted by other branches of the Allied armies fighting in hot climates.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: M3F2 Medium Combat Walker Assault Engineer "Steel Rain (Light)"
description: Maybe the most recognizable walker on the planet today, the Mickey chassis has given birth to a huge range of machines build on its rugged chassis. In the Pacific or the Middle-East, the Allies use a tropical version of the same chassis, whose main feature is an open top turret. The deadliest arsenal of the Mickey family stays the same. The Steel Rain mounts an impressive gun, capable of blowing any ground target on the planet to pieces.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Dust Tactics: M3G2 Medium Combat Walker Anti-Tank â "Barking Dog (Light)"
description:
Filling a gap in the Allied armoured arsenal between the M3A2 Mickey (Light) and the M3C Pounder, the M3G2 Barking Dog (Light) is an excellent anti-tank walker and can serve as a close support vehicle. Its six M40 recoilless guns fire in sequence, aimed at the same point thanks to a very advanced targeting system.

The sound of the guns firing a couple of seconds apart resembles a loud dog barking, hence the nickname of ‘Barking Dog’. This dog’s bite is far worse than its bark! Its 106mm rounds will easily destroy enemy fortified positions or blast tanks into smouldering heaps of metal.

The downside is the reload time needed to make this magic happen. All six guns need to be loaded from the outside of the vehicle, one at a time. That’s why you’ll rarely see a Barking Dog alone on the battlefield. It behaves more like a wolf than a dog, either traveling in pack of its own, or with other walkers that complement its role.

The Marines’ Light Barking Dog is similar to the prototype tested by the Army, but has an open-topped turret for better vision and cross-country performance. It is probably the most popular walker in the Marine Corps’ arsenal.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Defend the Village
description:
Defend the Village is a Cooperative Deck-Building game in which 1-5 heroes team up to save a village under distress from low-life bandits and hard-hitting villains! You take turns buying new weapons, potions and helpful items while also fighting off bandits before they destroy all six of your battlegrounds all the while praying you have enough strength to destroy all 5 villains! Do you and your fellow heroes have what it takes to defeat these villains and save this innocent village? Only time will tell…

Each player is dealt a random Hero with their own stats and ability. Each player also starts with the same starting hand. On each players turn they will reveal a card from the bandit deck and then spend the cards from their hand to purchase new items, or fight a Bandit or Villain.

Easy to learn, tough to survive.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Ruinstar
description:
One month ago, Star-ship union find an asteroid with many historical remains near the SiTan galaxy. One after another, treasure-hunters arrive this ruin star and search the treasure by the loading of symbols on remains' wall.
Now, it's time for you to show up. Players take a role of treasure-hunters. following the guide of map and racing to the finish first.
In the Ruinstar, draft randomly map-cards forming the race track, namely the map in current game. Also, players will take their own meeples and put them on the origin of map. During the game, players draft cards on the center and play them from hands on the front of themselves, acting as a their own exploration-cards colunm. Then, that player can get some symbols on the cards played by him and may use these symbols for other actions,such as destroy others' exploration-cards column or extra advance his/her meeple.
It's the most important and interesting that how to prevent others' plan and use your own symbols for advance on the map with Combos.

name: Populations
description:
Populations is an insanely addictive game about primitive fantasy races and their struggles to sort out who's land is who's!

Throughout the game, players will explore a vast and mysterious world in order to find useful resources and victory points. The various resources (i.e. stone, wood, textile) are used to grow population, build fantastic castles, and discover useful technologies.

Specifically, on a players turn, they may spend action points to increase and move their population around the map, and to build castles to secure lands. Additionally, players may always explore new lands by drawing new land tiles and adding them to the known world!

Depending on the number of players, a victory point goal is set at the beginning of the game. Once a player has achieved the preset goal on their turn, they win the game. Likewise, if a player eliminates all other players from the game, then they stand victorious!
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: 20 Level UP in 60 minutes
description:
The main point of this game is to level up fast through game experience. In this fantasy-themed game, your Hero can go up 21 levels in a single game session!

Players customize the powers of their heroes though rapid leveling up — with every passing round, their heroes gain experience and grow in power.

Heroes use abilities, tons of items, skills, and spells against enemy units in order to defend the Realm and find the Ancient Artifact before it's too late!

Each player will develop their own Hero during the game. .


There are also extra cards for a Players VS Player version of the game.


During the game:
Players may recruit new characters, take control of mines (which produce gold and resources for the Cities), and most importantly, defeat the enemy units which occupy the map and Dungeon.

Game-play:
On your turn, your Hero (Attack) rolls one dice (or more in higher Level) AND additional black dice for each enemy in your Location. If the number of your Hero rolled dice matches the number of a Item, Skill, Spell Card that your Hero owns, he gets the effect of that Card.
If the number of enemy rolled dice (black) matches the number on enemy Card, it deals damage to your Hero and gets the effect of own Card.

At the most of the time your Hero rolled die will trigger other Players Cards. Yes, a lot of cards may be activated by other Players rolls and the owner of the Card gains the effect.
After combat roll, your Hero may spend Experience points to get new Skill and Spell Cards, and spending gold for new Items (weapons, armors, items, scrolls).

END OF THE GAME
Lose: lost one of the main City OR lost all magic towers/mines OR then Dungeon population reached the max.
Win: find the ancient artifact in the Dungeon AND clear the main 3 Cities from the enemies.

Contains

Dice (36x):

d4 x15,
d6 x10,
d8 x5,
d10 x3,
d12 x2,
d20


Cards (486x)

Different Hero Cards: 16x
Different Item cards: 82x + enemy Units rewards 148x
Different Skill Cards: 156x
Different Spell Cards: 74x
Different Attachments Cards: 32x
Different Enemy Units Cards: 114x
Different Locations Cards: 54x
Different Event Cards: 46x


Large spell books Cards: 20x
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Dust 1947: Panzerspahlaufer I-H (Flak) â "Luft Heinrich"
description: This airborne operations ready walker is used in the Luftwaffe Ground Divisions. Thanks to its thrusters, it can be parachuted directly on the battlefield, joining the action as soon as the rest of the invasion force arrives. This model is tasked with destroying enemy attack planes and heavy infantry with the help of its powerful long range antiaircraft guns.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: War Cash
description:
War has a price and it's time to pay!
War Cash is a quick casual war game where players use Cash Cards to fund battle actions for fighting your opponents or to help you survive.

A 2 - 4 player game where all 12 Cash Cards are shuffled and players draw one Cash Card and bank or fully pay an action.

Any player can fully pay an action and use it - so the player needs to think - should they pay?
categories: Card Game, Economic, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Dungeons Are Dangerous!
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Dungeons Are Dangerous!, players will use their best excuses to avoid another adventure in a treacherous dungeon because...dungeons ARE DANGEROUS!

name: Teddy Hedz
description:
Teddy Hedz, or THZ for short, is a card game in which you attempt to hit your opponent repeatedly with a range of soft plush toy animal heads. The victor is rewarded with the right to hit their opponent with a real plush toy animal head, adding humiliation to failure.

Each round has a build phase, a battle phase and a draw phase. In the build phase players set up defenses, boost their abilities or initiate a battle. If a battle is declared, all players participate in the battle phase; pitting the skills of their THZ, as well as a variety of Buffs, Environments, Interrupts and Bearicades, in a duel. Winner scores virtual SCONs against their opponent. At the end of the battle, all players draw a card.

The first player to reach 10 SCONs — or the player with the most SCONs when the cards run out — wins and may claim the THZ to hurl at their opponent.

No actual teddy bears were harmed in the making of Teddy Hedz.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fighting, Miniatures, Print & Play
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Take That

name: Legal Cannabis
description:
Description from the publisher:

The era of black gold is over. An alternative to oil has existed for centuries: CANNABIS.

You find unoccupied land where CANNABIS grows in abundance. You purchase your first tractors right away. Your crops allow you to build factories that process the CANNABIS into several products. These products lead to contracts that bring in gold.

Beware of criminals who want to farm your CANNABIS. Protect yourself with the help of police.

Think and sow the CANNABIS seeds that will grow on your land. Build your factories at the right time and you will earn copious amounts of gold. Rise to the challenge by growing this natural resource!

EXPAND DESCRIPTION :
Buy land to sow cannabis seeds and harvest cannabis. Build factories to make products. Transport the products with trucks to win cards. Each card equals one gold coin. The winner is the first player who collect 4 gold coins.
categories: Environmental, Farming, Fighting, Industry / Manufacturing, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Forbidden: A Mature Party Game for Immature People
description:
Description from the publisher:

As we like to say, this game is not for the easily embarrassed, often offended, or humorless among you… Forbidden is a game for those of us that revel in watching our friends squirm, get flustered, and curse loudly. If this is you, then welcome to Forbidden!
All players split into teams and in each round one player will try to get his team to guess the target word, without using any of the Forbidden words listed on the card. If the player can get their teammates to guess the target word they score a point and move on to the next card, the object is to score as many points as possible in the time allowed. However, if the player messes up and uses a Forbidden word or says any part of the target word then the card and the point go to the other team. Additionally, if you are caught using any of the Forbidden words then you must draw a Forbidden card, these can be beneficial, but usually they are an additional obstacle that you must deal with on your next turn.
We also have four types of special cards included in the deck-
Skip- Allows you to skip past a difficult card without a penalty or without the other team getting a point.
Steal- This card allows your team to jump in for a round and try to guess the target words while the other team gives clues. Any words that you guess first will score a point for your team.
F@*K You- Use this card to pass the most challenging cards to the other team, they must start their turn with that card.
Wild- This card works as any one of the other cards, your choice!
That’s it, that’s all you need to know to play the game, simple right? However every game is unique based on who you play with and with a massive deck of Forbidden cards to play through you should expect countless hours of laughing at your friends.
Forbidden- A mature game, for immature people
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Word Game
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Paper-and-Pencil, Pick-up and Deliver, Team-Based Game

name: Stock Trader: The Stock Market Board Game
description:
Your rich uncle just gave you some investments. Can you make some smart moves and turn them into a fortune?

Stock Trader is a simple and fun stock market game that you can play solo or with the whole family. Do you have what it takes to be a smart investor on the stock exchange? Find out with Stock Trader, The Stock Market Board Game!

The objective of the game is to become the richest player by buying and selling stocks and gold. Buy low, and sell high!

The main board tracks the value of each investment. The value of each investment is increased or decreased by rolling dice each turn, if the positive die (green) is higher than the negative die (red), the value moves up that many spaces. If the red die is greater than the green die, the value drops and could even crash that stock completely! Each turn there is a new 'Headline News' card that can affect the stock values in addition to the dice rolls.

After the dice are rolled and the values set, each player decides what they would like to buy and sell and tracks their shares on their own 'Portfolio' card.

After 10-turns, everyone sells their investments and the player with the most money wins the game!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection, Stock Holding

name: Building Blocks of Life
description:
In ancient times, sorcerers divided nature into 5
elements: Air, Fire, Water, Earth and Lightning.
It has been said that these five elements are the
Building Blocks of Life.

Goal of the game : To collect the most element points in your spell book.

You have one visible preferred element and one secret preferred element and 5 to 12 cards in your hand (from 5 to 2 players).

you play elements cards from your hand on the table to create a Block of Life (BoL: one card of each element) or you swap your visible or secret element with another player (and draw a card).

When you create a BoL, you pick one for your spell book and discard the rest.

The game ends automatically when one of
the following situations occur a player collects a Block of Life (a set of 5 different elements) in his spell book or specific situations suche as a player empties his hand or the drawing pile becomes empty.

name: Make America Debate Again
description:
Description from the publisher:

Make America Debate Again is a non-political card game where you and your friends debate ridiculous, creative topics with logical or outlandish arguments.

Each player takes turns drawing topic cards which they will attempt to win based on a simple majority vote or by winning a debate against one of the other players.

First to five cards wins!

name: Spiele-Box
description:
Compilation of:
Wild Life (Ravensburger/Carlit, type B)
Grand Prix (Ravensburger)
Chess Race (Ravensburger)
Huckepack
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Educational, Environmental, Exploration, Racing
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Road Warrior: The Tabletop Touring Experience
description:
In Road Warrior: The Tabletop Touring Experience, players start the game by drafting their band members from a pool of near professionals. Based on some of your favorite rockstars, you will find yourself in good company. After assembling their ideal four-piece, they take their act to the road.

Each turn, players traverse a map of America playing shows and building fame. As they travel coast to coast, by drawing event cards they will run into some snags along the way (such as bus breakdowns and cancelled shows), but if luck is on their side they will also encounter some great windfalls (like hit singles or magazine features).

On their turns, players choose from a variety of actions. They will regularly drive around from city to city in their very own tour bus. Performing shows, by a simple roll of the dice, is a steady form of income in the form of points. Performing market research is a great way for players to figure out which cities are dying to see their band. Players will even find themselves challenging their opponents to turn the tides.

As the game progresses, players will be drawn around the map to cities that are craving shows, some even hosting huge festivals. Complete these shows in exchange for big rewards, but beware, bigger wins also mean bigger losses. Failing shows no matter the size will increase the tension within your band, and if you don't keep it under control, it may just lead to your band's demise!

Eventually, each player will find that their growing band has reached a point where they need some help. They can hire a variety of skilled roadies including bus drivers, guitar techs, sound engineers and more.

To emerge victorious as a true Road Warrior, players must reach level 3 on the point track and complete at least 3 of the 4 game end goals.
• Play each of the 4 industry cities
• Play at least 10 successful shows in your home region
• Hire 3 Roadies
• Successfully challenge each other player at least once
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Guess The Fake
description:
User Summary

A 2-5 player trivia game where the player who scores the most points wins. The trivia questions, score, game instructions and game moderator are all contained in the "Guess The Fake" electronic unit that houses everything you need to play the game.

Players will sit at one of the 5 colored stations on the unit and listen for instruction. The electronic unit randomly picks a trivia question in true/false format and then directs the question to one of the colored stations, which will flash when selected. The player then presses the button on their color station and then subsequently presses one of two buttons on the middle of the unit. The green button signifies true, while the red button signifies false. The player also has the option of challenging another player to answer the question. Answering wrong equals a two point penalty for the challenged player, while answering correctly nets the player 1 point.

The electronic unit also mixes in "quick" challenges randomly. In this type of challenge, the electronic will ask a question than any player an answer, but only the player that pushes their color station button first gets to answer the question and score a point.

The winner is the player with the most points, and a typical game is the first player to 20 points.

name: MALU
description:
MALU is an abstract strategy board game for 2 or 4 players.

Long ago, high up in the Himalayan mountains, a group of traveler monks known as the Malu, wandered through its snowy peaks. Their days were filled with prayer, meditation, and training. As part of their training, they played a single board game. The game was elegant in its simplicity, yet complicated in its mastery. For generations the game was a closely guarded secret and used by the monks to train new acolytes in the art of traversing the narrow passages and treacherous peaks of the Himalayas.

One day, while the monks were attempting to cross a particularly narrow bit of mountain, a copy of the game was swept away in a snowstorm. It was brought down the mountain by an avalanche and eventually recovered by a small boy from a remote village. The boy was so intrigued by the game that he left his home to wander the mountains, track down the monks and learn the ways of the Malu.

Many years passed and the boy eventually grew to be an intelligent man, possessing all the secrets of the Malu. He eventually returned to civilization and brought with him the game of the Malu. By sheer chance (or perhaps fate), he has deemed you a worthy challenger. It is now time for you to test your skills... Do you have what it takes to out-think and out-maneuver your opponent and cross the mountain pass in MALU?


The objective of the game is to move both your pawns across the map to the other side of the board and exit the map. The first player to have both their pawns exit the map wins.

The mechanics of the game are simple enough that anyone can pick up and start playing, but the depth of skill and many possible strategies to employ, allows for seasoned players to truly be masters of MALU.

Each turn, a player must move their pawn and place a neutral tile onto the board. As you place your tiles, adjoining tiles create paths that your pawns can move along. As your pawn moves, you have the ability to pick up those tiles and reroute them to your advantage... either as a path to the other side or as a means to block your opponents. But be careful... if you get too close, your opponent can snatch those tiles away from you and use them for themselves! You can also place walls of ice and mountain peaks as obstacles or knock down walls for strategic advantages.

Like many other classic games... first one to the finish wins! But in MALU, you will need to muster all your skill and cunning to make it past your opponent and be the first across the mountain pass.

name: Pod Station: Evacuate
description:
Description from the designer:

The pod station has suffered a catastrophic system failure. The crew is almost entirely missing, but those who survived the destruction made it to the main hub. There's only enough power left to launch one evacuation pod. You must begin to reconstruct the pod station. Move from pod to pod as the station takes on a new shape. Search through laboratories to find an evacuation key and other survival necessities. Access computers to find evacuation codes and detect problems within the station. Then, get to your evacuation pod to escape before it's too late!

In this modular board game, players must gain access to laboratories and computers in order to collect the cards necessary to evacuate. But, collecting isn't the only goal, as you must safely navigate your way to the correct Evacuation Pod to achieve the win. Fires, hull breaches, and power failures may need to be dealt with along the way.

The game can be played solo as a survival game or with friends as a cooperative or competitive game. There are also several alternate game "scenarios" that alter rules, remove cards, and add more challenging limitations to the game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Set Collection, Take That, Tile Placement

name: Napoleon and his Marshals
description:
This is a strategic and operational scale game of the central European theaters of the Napoleonic Wars (France, Austria, Prussia, N. Italy, 1805-1815).

Napoleon and his Marshals covers 1805-1815 in France and Central Europe. Other expansions are underway that will add the Peninsular War, the Patriotic War in Russia and maps of Scandinavia and the rest of Italy. The game is strategic and operational. Each strategic turn is two months, broken down into 6 10-day operational turns.Forces are division level (5,000 men) per factor, with artillery, cavalry, Cossacks, and guerillas as additional specialized units. Leaders are included at the National Military Leader (Napoleon, Kutusov, etc.), Army commanders, and marshals/corps commanders. Combat units for 11 nations are included. In the expansions the naval war is added, with Nelson, other British Admirals, along with French, Spanish, and Russian admirals, and the navies of those countries and Denmark and Sweden, along with the armies of Spain and Portugal.

This is the basic game, required to play all other expansions and the campaign game, which will run from January 1805 through the end of 1815 or the final victory. Included is a 31" x 23.5" map, printed on plastic coated reinforced "banner" paper (which is rolled up for storage), and 5 counter sheets of 88 counters, printed front and back, and slightly larger than traditional counters at 0.6" square. Map scale is about 28 miles to 38 miles per hex (depending on where you are on the map).

During the Strategic Turns, nations collect taxes (production) and expend it on organization and units, including leader activation, replacements, new units, mobilization, sea lift capacity, foreign aid, supplies, and other items. Diplomacy may also occur. During the ensuing 6 operational turns, leaders and units are moved, battles fought, sieges undertaken and possibly diplomacy is conducted.

There are six scenarios in the game: 1805 (vs Austria, Britain and Russia), 1806-07 (vs Prussia, Britain and Russia), 1805-1807 (vs all four), 1809 (vs Austria, Russia and Britain), 1813-1815 (vs all four), and 1815 (the 100 days of Napoleon's second reign). A player-turn takes about 5-15 minutes, so along with a strategic turn, a full "season" (two months is the length of a strategic turn and its associated operational turns) takes about 1.5 - 2.0 hours - less if there are no battles, more if there are many big battles.

name: Lost in Narration
description:
A fast interactive battle of narration, between 2 to 6 wizard storytellers, on 4 fantasy themed stories. +

In this game, wizard storytellers compete in forming and completing four different stories. They all have great ideas to propose for each story theme, but who has the best ones? You are a fantastic wizard storyteller: Manage your story cards – place them on the board as parts of stories or discard them. Gather fantasy coins, buy spells and cast them wisely. Your goal is to add parts of stories and complete them, in order to score story points. The more spectacular a story is, the more points it’s worth, but to whom? The best contributors score, but the storyteller with the final word gets extra credit!

name: Le Voleur
description:
Paris, the city of lights, love and arts. An exotic location with all its glory. Unfortunately, it is also a perfect place for an act of heist! In Le Voleur (the thief), you will gather a team of thieves trying to steal loots from various districts in downton Paris. Be mindful with your steps because not only you have to plan carefully and dodge the patrolling police, but rumor says there are other teams trying to expose you! Be careful with your planning and notes, because even a slightest mistake might ruin your perfectly planned heist!

Le Voleur is a logic-strategic game for 2 to 4 players. There are 2 main mechanics going on: the main board with area control and player board with deduction. On the main board, players need to create patterns by flipping colored tokens. With the right pattern, players can Scout and finally Steal the good. To flip the tokens, players need to use one of the Abilities of their agents, 4 are taken randomly from bag at setup, by turning their Agent's dial to show the desired abilities (shared color with the token on the board). Other players may mark these abilities on their player board, called Headquarter, which also shows the identity of all agents available in the game. Everytime an Agent use their abilities these clue grows and eventually reveal the Agent correct identity.
The game played in 8 turns. Each turn are consist of several phases and each phase shows how many agents a player can play. If a player have less than 4 agents, he eventually lost all ability to use any actions on that phase and can only recruit new agents. Victory Points are collected by either Steal a Good or exposing other Agents. The first player with 5 Victory Points wins the game.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deduction, Pattern Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Sienna in the Stars
description:
Abstract dice-rolling game created by five-year old Holly Stallard, and published by Games 4 Geeks.

Using a single dies, players roll to see who will win, depending on the outcome of the die.

This is essentially a gag game, as the way the designer (who as stated above is five) has created the rules, the youngest player can't fail to win.
Whether this was originally intentional, or just a lucky accident on the designer's part is currently unknown.

name: One Last Job
description:
One Last Job is a strategy card game for two players that plays out in about 30 minutes. One player takes the role of the Crew, assembling a team of operatives with specialized equipment and using daring tactics to pull off a heist. Meanwhile, the other player acts as The Powers That Be, secretly laying traps and deploying countermeasures while working to grow their influence over the city. Can the Crew get in and get out before The Powers complete their nefarious scheme?

One Last Job features hidden information, bluffing, and calculated risks as both players outwit and adapt to each other. In this seedy world of corruption and evil agendas, nothing is certain. An apparently easy heist can quickly go south due to unforeseen complications, while a near impossible one can be miraculously pulled off. Everything action and counteraction is a dangerous gamble for both sides.

Weather you want to play the classic heist of an elite professional team taking on the mafia to settle a score, or perhaps something more fantastical, One Last Job has you covered. Ever wonder how a group of 90s hackers would fare at preventing a world crisis by an evil mastermind? Or if you could get wacky street gangs to put aside their in-fighting to steal the knowledge of a secret society? One Last Job features six factions (three for each side), each with their own unique strategies and flavor.
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Secret Unit Deployment, Variable Player Powers

name: Slipstream
description:
Slipstream is a compact card game for 2-4 players in which you take the role of scientists fighting your way through shifting dimensions to reach your control panel to return to your dimension. You are in a race across the 25 laboratory cards between you and your control panels. Each player gets a 'Slipstream Gun' card that allows them to warp themselves or others to different dimensions. Some dimensions contain cards that make the trip across the board easier, while other dimensions make the journey more perilous. Players must balance their urge to race across the board with their need to blast other players into neighboring dimensions. To win, a player must make it across the lab to their own control panel.

Each turn every player gets to perform one movement action and one 'Slipstream Gun' action. The movement action allows the players to move their token to a neighboring card, edging ever closer to their control panel, and victory. For their 'Slipstream Gun' action, players can choose to shoot any player (sending them to another dimension) or they can 'recalibrate' their gun by flipping the card over. This changes what dimension players will go to when shot with the 'Slipstream Gun'.

Players start at one end of a 4x5 card grid. Their control panels are on the opposite side. All of the laboratory cards are face down and as players move on to each card, it is flipped face up and the events on the face of the card are incurred. These can offer benefits like moving forward or gaining an item card. They can also be negative like losing a turn or being sent to the 'Dark World' a dimension in which the cards are much more challenging.

The game ends when any player is able to make it all the way across the board and steps on to the colored control panel that matches their player token.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Take That

name: Clean Up Your Room!
description: Clean Up Your Room! is a family friendly card game with a simple goal: score the most points while trying to get all of the objects off your room floor. On each player's turn, she can put an object, such as power tools or a pink fairy armadillo, one of her pieces of furniture. She might also steal an object from a sibling's room floor. Or, she might throw something from her room into another room. Players can also use event cards to mix things up, but sometimes they have unexpected consequences like making animals run from room to room! When one player's room floor is clear of objects, the game ends. All players count up points for objects put away plus any bonus points and subtract one point for any objects left on their room floors.

name: Highest Bidder: Art Auction
description:
In Highest Bidder: Art Auction players are faced with three paintings each round and bid on them using cards from their hands. Decide on the order in which you want to play your cards, then at the count of three all players place their bids simultaneously; you don't know how many cards each player will bid, nor what might lurk inside the bids. Cards are then revealed one at a time.

Cash cards - starting at $10,000 and going as high as $70,000 - are mixed with strategic effect cards and this is where the game becomes truly exciting! When an effect card is revealed it takes effect immediately. Effects include "Draw a random card", "Shuffle the bid pile of an opponent", "Next card is invalid", "Swap a card with an opponent", and more. Laugh-out-loud moments often occur as bids don't play out as planned and unforeseen circumstances appear. Your effect cards can even end up hurting yourself.

"Highest Bidder: Art Auction" is based on the original game "Highest Bidder". With brand new and highly detailed artwork, larger cards of better quality, 16 brand new "advanced cards" not seen in the original game, and an "advanced play" rule book on top of the base game, the "Highest Bidder: Art Auction" box is packed with goodies and hours of fun!
mechanics: Action Queue, Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Monkey Wrench: Deluxe Edition
description:
Description from the designer:

Monkey Wrench 2nd Edition:

Your company is firing employees; Can you get rid of the bad employee in time?

Monkey Wrench

Is a social deduction and manipulation game requiring a minimum of 7 people to play, (6 "Employees" & 1 Narrator). The concept of the game is rather simple. The company you work for, has suddenly been having problems with all of its production machines being sabotaged by an unknown person After hours. The Security footage shows that One of your fellow employees, (players) has been seen tampering with the machines, "After Hours". The problem is, the security system couldn't detect who it was. Worse, every employee has an alibi, and no one is willing to step forward with any information of evidence.

There for, the Board of Directors, (The Narrator(s)), have decided that one employee will be fired during each "Day Shift" via a 60% majority Employee vote, until the machines are no longer being tampered with each night. To help facilitate this, members of the local law enforcement (Undercover Cop) and the FBI (in larger games of over 15 players), as well as other law enforcement agencies (NSA 20 player game, CIA 25 player game ) to help catch the potential criminals involved. They are also working diligently around the clock to help your company find the culprit. Meeting in secret "After hours" to arrest potential suspects, while also masquerading as a regular employee. Their goal, is to help weed out the real problem person; The elusive The Monkey Wrench and their crew of saboteurs.

However, the members of the Monkey Wrench team have an edge:
Once per "After hours" phase, they can secretly convert one of the other employee towards their goal. If they manage to convert a casual non titled "Employee", that person becomes a leader within their team, and will be given a "Monkey Wrench" card to show their loyalty. Additionally, depending on the size of the "company (game), other criminal elements can also be expected to try to infiltrate the entire organization. Everything from a simple, "Lunch Thief", to a "Cat Burglar", to even members of a Cult, as well as various types of "Hackers", Espionage experts and even a Corporate embezzler. Each with their own "After hours" abilities that can be used by the Monkey Wrench team, IF they can figure out who within the company is what. Which keeps the members of Law enforcement busy during the game, and helps ensure that the Monkey Wrench team will over throw the company.

Fortunately; the Law enforcement team, (Security guard, Undercover cop, FBI, CIA, NSA.. etc..), do have a extra tools in their wheel house to counter this influx of added trouble. For starters at the end of every "After hours" phase, the company "Security Guard" has the ability to The "sense" when another Employee can been involved with an illicit activity that evening. While the Undercover cop, once per After hours round can "Arrest" a single potential suspect. That player is then removed from game the next subsequent "Day shift". While the FBI agent, has the power to literally "Fire" anyone one person in the company. Either as a secret executive action during the "After hours" round, or by revealing themselves to the other players as a member of law Enforcement. Upon which they can then have executive power to remove the undercover CEO, or members of upper management and even overthrow their power position within the game. While the NSA has the power to make various "hacking' actions, while the CIA player, has the ability to be a spy in any group, and never reveal themselves, unless they want to. Each member of Law Enforcement, are thus granted unique abilities to help them thwart the dastardly goals of the criminal elements in game. However, in turn, each has their own requirements that they must fulfill in order to win the game.

However; the rest of the employees, and neutral parties can also use their individual abilities, as well as their natural powers of social deduction, interaction, and situational perceptions to determine who they should "vote" against during the "Day shift" round. That way they can work together to have 1 of their fellow employees (Players), removed from game as a group in hopes to help the Law Enforcement players remove threats from the game, and win by power of democratic unity.

So its up to you fellow employee…

Will you side with the Monkey Wrench and take down the company?
Will you help the Corporate Security to weed out the problem person?
Or... are you secretly the Monkey Wrench, all along? Manipulating everyone to help you shut down the company.

General game play:
Each player is given 4 cards at the beginning of the game:

1 - "Day shift" card, which denotes their public role within the company, that every other player is completely aware of. This card reflects that players normal operations within the company during the day, while they are working. It further operates as each players "titled" position within a standard normal office environment. Each titled position, is sometimes granted certain abilities, that are usually made public to all players in play, during the "Day shift" phase.

1 - "After hours" card. which designates the given players roles, duties and Private activities when they are not at work, during the "After hours" phase of the game. During this phase of game play, some players are lumber into various secret shadow groups, that operate in secret. Some of them are trying to resolve the crime within the company. Others are trying to ruin the company, by either overthrowing it (Such as the Monkey Wrench), or corrupting the internal operations of the company. While others yet still, have absolutely little value, or influence upon the companies operations, and function as nothing more than benign red herrings, to offset the various groups investigations.

1 - "Vote/ Fire" card. This Operates as each individual players ability to either support another players choice of someone that they believe should be removed from play, (The "Vote" side of the card), by holding the card up above their head, showing that they cast a vote in support of the accuser against the one person they believe should be removed from game. Or on their "Current player" turn (When they have the "Current player" puck in hand), they may select one player in the room to be "Fired" from game, by pointing the card at the person they suspect is guilty, or should be removed from game. If they manage to gain a 65% majority supporting vote from the other remaining players in the game, the selected person is removed from game, revealing their "After hours" card(s). They then regardless of how the vote ended, had the card off to the next player to their Left.

1 - "Gestures" card. This card is a reference card of common hand gestures used during the "After hours" phase of the game. This helps players know what other players in the group they are part of are saying to them, and allows them to communicate in a sort of crude sign language with each other and the Narrators.



Average game time:
15 minutes for a 7 to 10 person game
30 minutes for a 10 to 15 person game
45 minutes for a 15 to 20 person game
60 minutes for a 20 to 30 person gameIntended age of play:
This game is intended for persons 16 years or older. However, the production website says "18", only because the options, are 12 or 18. The content that is questionable, within the game, is sexually suggestive adult humor, found within 4 "After hours" cards. Which are not essential for general game play, and may be removed as needed for smaller games, of less than 25 persons playing, if persons playing the game are not age appropriate for the setting.

Number of players:
A basic game consists of at least 7 to 10 players:
Advanced games can handle 11 to 33 players.

Please note, however that for every 10 "Employee" players in the game, 1 "Board member" (Narrator), will be needed, as this will help the Narrator's to be able to manage remembering who is what position, has been fired, or changed roles within the game. A "Employee Roster" is provided within the game to help facilitate this, however larger games can get very confusing quickly, and to accommodate this, it's strongly advised to use 1 additional Narrator per 10 players.

Contents:
1 - 60 second timer
1 - 120 second timer
1 - pencil
1 - "Employee Roster" score pad (Player role tracker)
1 - "Current player" card
30 - "Hand gesture" reference cards
30 - "Voting/ "Fire" cards
8 - Special effect cards (Used to reflect game modifiers, such as "Lunch Thief", Hacks, or other rule modifiers)
37 - "Day Shift" - Character employment cards (These roles, Everyone in play will know about)
93 - "After hours" split between different "Hobbies", "Scandals", "Skill's", & "Moonlighting" jobs.
1 - 40 page "Employee's Manuel" (Rule book)
1 - 32 page "Occupational Directory" (Card Description book)
1 - Deluxe sized box. To hold all your expansions.

Get your copy of Monkey Wrench 2nd Edition today!
https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/monkey-wrench-2nd-editi...
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Political, Real-time
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Memory, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Spellfire: Booster Pack, Set 13 â Inquisition
description: Spring 2001 - Titled both to put the magazine Inquest into its place (the magazine loved to mock out favorite game), and to show we survived Wizard's inquisition of old TSR properties, Inquisition made the game thrive once more. It sought to fix the problems found in tournaments with current rules and cards. Instead of adding new card types or worlds, it lets the fans speak as Mike "The Ogre" Huebbe create the set and made it official for all tournaments and play. The cards can be downloaded and there is also an official on-line guide (Reviewing an Inquisition). It had 99 cards with no chase so it would easily fit into page holders. Landmark Cards: Castle Arborgate (#1), The Shadowlands (#2), Arena of Dori the Barbarian (#3), Castle Moovania (#12), Mij Retlub, the Spellfire Oracle (#14), Dragon Mountain Kobald (#20), The Grim Reaper (#26), Etarkine (#31), The Gathering (#43), The Apocalypse (#47), Guild of Adventurers (#52), Ogre's Horned Helm (#67), Slap! (#78), Dispel Illusion (#83), and Mimic (#88).
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading

name: Spellfire: Booster Pack, Set 14 â Millenium
description: Spring 2002 - This second on-line booster came out in 2002. This was produced by the "Spellfire Triumverate": Mike Huebbe (repressenting the judges), Steve Naus (representing retail), and Hayden William Courtland (representing the fans). Again, based on fan suggestions, they created a 99 card set. However, they added a new concept to Spellfire that has been in Dungeons & Dragons for years: dice. Many cards required rolls to find their effects or level. While protested by some fans, the set has gotten general approval and is the most recent part of the canon and tournament scene. These cards, like Inquisition, can be downloaded and have an un-official guide in process (Grading a Millenium). Landmark cards: Duergar (#1), Aurumvorax (#8), Feinoue, Void Shaper (#14), Cockatrice (#17), Doomgrinder (#21), Rigged Dice (#22), Corruption (#29), Amish Nick (#41), Insanely Good Fortune (#47), Two Fisted Player (#51), Kronos the titan (#62), Poisoned Oasis (#68), Gellidus, Dragon of Ice (#73), Hornung's Randomness (#78), Bansmareton (#79), Wealthy Oriental Vassal (#81), Elven Towers (#89), Stomp (#92), and Stunning Fist (#98).
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading

name: Assassin's Guild
description:
A push your luck your luck card game where players compete to eliminate marks and collect bounties set by the Assassin's Guild.
The player with the biggest pile of gold at the end wins.

The game is a set of quick rounds, mark cards go up on the Guild notice board each with a variable bounty depending on which method is used to dispose of the target. Players have 4 cards representing different kill methods and 3 attempts per round to eliminate the marks.

Assassins play their attempt face down so everyone knows who your going for but not how. Using a gun is quicker but is worth little, while arranging an accident pays much better, but takes more time. The quickest assassin to get to a mark wins the bounty. Should two assassins use the same method however thing get awkward and neither gets the kill.

Players also compete to complete several missions laid out by the guild so that they an become assassin of the month and have the power to tip off the fuzz to harass their rivals.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Push Your Luck, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Moneytime
description:
Description from the designer:

Moneytime is a basketball card game that aims to deliver the sensations of a basketball game.

Each player plays a team and plays each basketball possession to try to score baskets, and playing defense and offense alternatively (like basketball).

By playing his offensive cards against the defensive cards in the possessions, the player playing offense will try to build an advantage to score using basketball actions with the ball, and without the ball wisely to avoid turnovers.

Simple and fast paced, Moneytime is designed around the notion of time, where individual highlights and simple collective mechanics are key, while shots at the buzzer and crazy end games are not rare.

Sound from a basketball perceptive, it remains true to the spirit of the game and reflects how basketball is to be played.

Typically a two players game, It can also be played by up to six players.

name: Stormy Moment
description: This is the fifth game of Kilovolt Design's tactical mini wargame series "Winning or Losing". The theme is Battle of Vukovar during Croatian War of Independence. The game is 2 in 1: Battle of Vukovar and Battle of East Croatia.

name: Runicah
description:
Runicah is a Norse themed, competitive card game that uses set collection, resource management, blind trade, and self serving cooperation mechanics to bring players on a journey of back-stabbing, back-tracking and back-scratching.

Players will compete to be the first to complete their own unique set of runes. Players will almost certainly need to cooperate on some level if they wish to win, the key is how and when to help each other out.

The game consists of a single repeated round sequence until a winner is determined. Each player starts with a Character card; which gives them a unique player ability and a starting Rune drawn, all of which are randomly dealt. Players then all draw loot cards which make up the resource they use to complete trials and hopefully obtain more runes.

A round consists of players completing personal trials, trading of runes, and a group event. A player wins when they have completed a sets, either the same colour with one of each symbol, or the same symbol with one of each colour. The main focus comes from player interactions during the trials and trading parts to the round, with players deciding whether cooperation is personally beneficial enough to risk helping an opponent.

A game can last anywhere from 20 to 40 mins depending on group size, and is balanced in such a way as to count noone out until the very end.

name: DC Universe Miniature Game: Darkseid
description: This expansion to the DC Universe Miniature game introduces Darkseid-the big bad of the DC Universe. This white metal kit comes ready to assemble and paint.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: butt wasted
description:
The game is simple - be the first player to get from start to "finished". The first player to reach the “finished” space wins. Once someone wins, move everyone back to start, reshuffle cards and start playing your ridiculous hearts out again—your liver and a fuzzy selection of potentially bad decisions will be there to thank you later.

Each player rolls the die, moves their game piece and follows what the space on the board tells them to do. The space can say anything from "take a drink", "give away a drink" or draw an individual or social card – and this is where things get interesting. Cards may instruct an individual to complete an activity, answer a question, or interact with other players in a specific way. The goal being to get to know the players around you OR simply be entertained by your friends in new and hilarious ways.

name: North Vs. South: A Civil War Card Game
description:
Description from the designer:

A card based strategy card game where players are trying to secure the most cities as possible before the fight between the North and South is over.

Players will obtain cities as they go and try to hold as many as possible by placing defense cards to protect and keep them.

Other players will use attack cards to attack the cities and acquire them, while drawing from the deck. Drawing from the deck will allow players to build their army and obtain free cities to keep and defend.

The game ends when Abe Lincoln, the Emancipation Proclamation, Gettysburg address and Appomattox courthouse are drawn. The players with the most cities at the end of the game wins.
categories: American Civil War, Card Game, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Chroma Quarrel
description:
HOW TO PLAY
Chroma Quarrel is a card game in which players play colored cards from two decks - each representing the player's health and attacks/play direction.

Cards are played face-down, the cards are revealed at the same time and the highest card wins. If the attacking player wins, then they deal damage. Players lose health and if the player runs out of cards from their health deck, they are eliminated out of the game. However, if their attack hand is depleted, they can spend health cards to stay in the fight!

The last player standing, wins!
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Number, Print & Play

name: Release Animal
description:
HOW TO PLAY
In Release Animal, there are 66 animal cards, each with an elemental affiliation: Fire, Water, Earth, Timber and Gold. Each card also has an animal type: mouse, cat, dog, wolf, tiger, elephant and dragon.

Each player is dealt a hand of cards, depending on the number of players. Players use cards to fight against the other players - depending on the type of animal or the elemental quality depends on whether they can defeat the defender.

For example, cat eats mouse, dog eats cat and mouse, etc. However, the elemental affiliation can swing the fight - a water cat can defeat a fire dog. As long as play can play a card, they may continue to discard cards.

HOW TO WIN
Player who discards all of their cards first, wins the game.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: A Voyage of Our Own
description:
Today is finally your day!
The emperor finally granted you a permit and even a ship!

In your anticipation you rush to see your magnificent ship and find...

Your 3 rivals already arguing over whose voyage it is!!

In A Voyage of Our Own, you play an intrepid explorer
forced to share their ship with 1-3 other explorers to explore an unknown archipelago.
Can you claim more credit for the voyages success?

Or will one of the other explorers steal the glory for
themselves?

...Set sail and adventure east to the Vooo islands.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Voyage of Our Own is a light strategy exploration game. Players share the ship's crew to earn more credit for the voyage. This is done by placing and exploring islands, laying claims on tiles, and collecting tiles in their hands.

Credit is earned by discovering islands, claiming tiles, and gathering sets of trade goods. The player with the most credit at the end of the game wins.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Voyage of Our Own contains
24 Hex tiles.
2 Crew
1 Board
1 Cool down chip
60 Claims (15 in 4 colours)

name: Cy-Co: The Western Cyberpunk Board Game
description:
Cy-Co is a western cyberpunk strategy game for 2 to 4 players. It combines classical western elements with the cyberpunk style of the 80s.

Alternately Cy-Co and Crime Evil perform their actions. When both players have finished their rounds the civilians move with their own card deck randomly on the game board – trying to escape the villain Crime Evil in panic.

In order to achieve their goals, the players have to strategically outmaneuver each other and thus thwart the machinations of their adversary. Who will prevail in this epic showdown of Cy-Co, the western cyberpunk board game – law or anarchy?
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Unfairy
description:
Description from the designer:

Unfairy is a game where each player assumes the role of a peculiar fairy tale character who wants to be the hero of its own tale. Fight against popular fairy tales characters and win magical items that will get you stronger by stealing and annoying your opponents. At the start of the game every player gets a character and a characteristic that changes the way the player will have to play that match. You can play as a hysterical fairy, a faint-hearted knight or a headless mage. There are 400 different combinations to play with.

In Unfairy each player receives 5 cristals that works as its attributes and are used as resources to, in alternate turns, activate their magical items, fight encounters, steal from its opponents and search for the objective encounter to fight it and win the game before your opponents.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Project Spera
description:
Description from the designer:

Project Spera is a cooperative 2 - 4 player survival horror game inspired by games like the original Resident Evil and Silent Hill, that uses deck building, tile exploration, and variable player powers.

The year is 2136. For centuries now the world has been overrun with monsters, demons, and any other number of unspeakable horrors. A team of scientists and historians have traced everything back to a single cataclysmic event in a war torn 1940's, when the axis powers tore a hole in the fabric of reality.
Humanity is on the verge of extinction, and Project Spera, is its last hope...

In Project Spera, players take on the role of a team of people salvaging the remains of a device that was once meant to save the world. Players will need to explore a hidden facility, arm themselves with what limited resources they can afford, and work together to defeat the creatures within. The game is won when the final boss is defeated, and the cataclysm is averted.

You are all alone, your resources limited, and the horrors within leave you on the edge of insanity. Will you survive? Or will you succumb to the darkness…and be lost…forever?
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Test of Honour: The Samurai Miniatures Game â Oda Nobunaga
description:
Oda Nobunaga was a key figure in the Japnese civil wars. This card adapts the character o Nobunaga to the tabletop for use in Test of Honour games.

The card allows Oda Nobunaga to be fielded as a Special Character, complete with some enhanced combat skills and special rules that make him a unique addition to one's forces.

The miniature pictured on the card os from the Wargames Illustrated 'Giants in Miniature' range.

The card is available for download from the Wargames Illustrated website.
categories: Civil War, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Renaissance, Wargame
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: Sugar Rush
description: Created in response to an almost-four-year-old's request for a board game based on her favourite movie, Sugar Rush is a relatively simple racing game designed for children, based thematically on the fictional video game Sugar Rush, from the Disney movie Wreck-it Ralph. Players assume the role of a racer, setup at the starting line, and then take turns rolling dice for their movement around the race track. Each racer has a unique ability that they can charge-up during the race and then use to their advantage. Racers can also gain Power Ups, which are drawn from a randomized deck of Power Up cards. First across the finish line gets 8 Gold Coins, second place gets 5 Gold coins, and third place gets 2 Gold coins. The racer with the most coins at the end wins.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: King Cat
description:
King Cat is a new board game in which Cat Lovers must attract the Cat inside their home, while Cat Haters must kick him out of the garden.

Bazooka, Mice Cake, Vacuum Blender, Inflatable Cat, Alien Kidnapping, Dark Ritual… are all part of the numerous tricks and powers that players have at their disposal to gain some control over the Cat and win the game.

Trick is, the Cat also has his word to say and can choose to ignore players or take his own action, like refusing to move at all.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Humor
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Redemption City
description:
After the apocalypse, the Earth is all but destroyed, save for the last city. The few remaining humans who were neither good enough for Heaven nor evil enough for Hell are stuck in limbo, held on Earth. Angels and Demons wage war against each other across the universe, trying to gain control where they can. They care not for the humans in limbo, for their souls won’t ever be released to them. As the Earth is removed of most humans, nature has decided to take back what is left, to consume the land with their plants once more.

The final Battle for earth begins!


This is a strategy game for 2 - 5 players, where you build your base, gain resources, and send units to build or attack.

The game takes place on a 10 by 10 grid, with each player choosing a race, then placing them at the relevant starting location (dependent on the number of players). Each player then takes it in turns to spawn units, take two actions for each unit (move, build or attack), constructing buildings that will either give them money (for building and upgrades), weapon tokens (for attacking and defending) for creating more units (for making actions). Players can build in an empty space, so long as they have the resources, however if the space has an enemy building, they can attack+build (redemption!) to create a building of one level higher than that attacked (for the cost of a lower level building). After each player has taken a turn, you roll for obstacles (Meteorites, etc) which can land anywhere and destroy buildings, whilst also being "Redeemed" by players to give them an easy higher level building.

Each race has their own goal, such as to own the majority of the board, along with a unique ability that aids them in this goal.

Once a player has reached this goal, they win the game after one more round.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Science Fiction, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Honest Rabbits
description:
[Honest Rabbits] is the card games for Kids.

The most "honest" player can win a victory!
The winning strategy is to trust and to be trusted.

- Going to forward with Reliable friends!!!
With the simple rule, anybody are able to do this game easily. At first, you should try to align three cards in your hands with colors, number or in a row. You must get the forth card from another player. You can choose whom you trust to win together.

If anyone will achieve in the next turn, let you shout "I have that card!" regardless of whether you have it or not.

You are honest, aren't you?

name: KhromaZones
description:
KhromaZones is a quick, family-friendly game that plays competitively, cooperatively or solo, where you use colorful gemstone cards to claim zones and score points.

Each player uses their hand of colorful cards to claim zones and score points. The more claimed zones in a row, the more points. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Set Collection

name: Three Little Kittens
description:
A player begins by spinning four and then chooses one of the two identical paths to move on.
Along the paths are spaces which are numbered. If a player lands on one of these spaces they must return to the numbered space before it. There are also white spaces to be found along the path. A player landing on any of these spaces loses two turns.
