The race is driven by players rolling 2 types of dice, engine dice which are numbered 1-6 to determine a ships speed and the pilot die which corresponds to one of the 6 pilot colors giving the rolled pilots ship a bonus.

High tensions will rise in this head to head all out race to the finish line. When the dice hit the table will you be in the winners circle?
-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The G.O.O.D Game: Get Out Of Dodge
description: Contains intentionally hateful racist material and appears to be a product of alt-right hatemongers.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Negotiation, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: The Price of Honor: The Battle of Callao, May 1866
description:
Price of Honor details the battle of Callao fought on May 2nd, 1866. The South American countries of Peru, Bolivia and Chile united in defying the Spanish government access to the nitrate rich Chincha Islands, and over other trade issues. Anti-Spanish riots and atrocities against Spanish citizens in these nations led to Spain ordering a powerful squadron of warships, led by the ironclad battleship Numancia, to seize the Chincha Islands and blockade their coasts. This was a flagrant violation of the Monroe Doctine, and the US and British governments also sent squadrons of warships to the area to monitor the situation, and possibly intervene against the Spanish fleet.

After taking the islands and announcing a blockade the Spanish Admiral Casto Mendez Nuñez announced that unless reparations were paid and apologies given by the South American Allied nations to Spain, the Spanish ships would begin attacking their shipping and ports. This threat was made reality on March 31st when the Spanish warships bombarded Valparaiso, Chile. The port was largely defenseless and unable to effectively resist. Emboldened, the Spanish fleet moved onto Callao where the bulk of the Allied warships and commercial shipping had concentrated. The port defenses here were more substantial and armed with modern guns, including five massive 22 ton Blakely guns in armored turrets, as well as bolstered by two ironclads, the Loa and Victoria. Learning that two new Peruvian ironclads, the Huascar and Independencia, were also about to arrive, Admiral Nuñez ordered an attack on May 2nd, despite the looming presence of the American and British warships whose leaders threatened to intervene.

The Spanish fleet’s attack at Callao was violent and damaging. Nearly 6,000 shells were fired by the Spanish ships alone, causing many casualties and much damage to the port’s defensive works and Allied warships. The Spanish fleet, however, also suffered with several of their warships severely damaged, crippled, or nearly sinking by the end of the afternoon when Admiral Nuñez ordered the Spanish fleet to break off and retire. Although inconclusive both sides claimed victory. Can you do as well or better than your historical counterpart?

Each copy of The Price of Honor is composed of the following:

One 11 by 17 inch hex map
Two sheets of 242 (total) single-sided, unmounted counters
One Players' Aid Sheet
Seven pages of rules

Price of Honor is designed by Paul Rohrbaugh with graphics by Bruce Yearian. The game uses the same card draw design as in A Bold Fight: The Battle of Mobile Bay, Duel of Iron: The Battle of Hampton Roads (already published) and the forthcoming games in Albemarle Sound (Thunder Upon the Water), Head of Passes/Forts Jackson and St. Philip (No Time For Prayer).

An optional card set for the game is also available. It replaces the standard deck of playing cards, features graphics by Bruce Yearian, and has rules reminders on pertinent cards.

name: Dragon Stories
description:
Dragon Stories is a story telling euro style game that utilizes modified worker placement and area control set in the fantasy world of the Arcturian nations. The mighty Dragon Weyr has withdrawn their protection from the peoples of the land due to corruption and mistrust between the various races. The leaders of the nations no longer believe that an outside threat exists which could harm their realm and have begun to manipulate the dragons into attacking their new found local enemies. The Dragon Weyr viewed these actions as a violation of the ancient code set forth at the beginning of time and have thusly withdrawn their support from the land. However, not all people are corrupt in the land. The sacred religious council set up by Arcturias himself still holds hope that the hearts of the corrupted can be turned virtuous again in time. The council has therefore laid the burden of traveling throughout the land to sway the ancient protectors, upon you. If you accomplish the task of reinstating the ancient code, the evil that lurks in the shadows will be too weak to overthrow the local kingdoms.
In Dragon Stories, 1-6 players will manage stats on their individual player boards similar to an engine building game. The stats on the board also act as currency in the game. Stat labels are ranged / melee weapons, defensive armor, magical talents and various skills depending on the player board making Dragon Stories uniquely asymmetrical. Players will interact with the game itself through stories written on cards. Tough decisions will have to be made to convince the ancient dragons to help protect the realm. Players will manipulate a modified worker placement system. Player board stats will have the ability to be improved and players will have to defend the land from invading forces and possibly other players. Ultimately though, if players do not figure out how to work together, the impending evil will take over the land. Additionally, the invading evil is also seeking to persuade the dragons to destroy the people of the land. Enemy forces will accomplish this through a game driven worker placement mechanic which ultimately ends up limiting players worker placement choices as the game progresses. The only way to stop the enemy is through area control and persuading the dragons to honor the old code.
Dragon Stories also features different ways to play to suit differing play styles. Players can play full coop mode which is an all win or all lose style game. Players can also choose to either play semi cooperatively or strictly competitively. In the end, you will tell your own Dragon Stories.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: UFO a Go-Go
description:
UFO a Go-Go is a game about following hilarious rules and calling out your friends when they slip up.

It’s party season throughout the galaxy and everyone is hosting a spectacular celebration! But who is going to be crowned Intergalactic Party Captain… Is it you?

Invite Aliens to your party - just don’t forget to be a good host for your guests and provide each of them the attention they deserve. If an Alien feels neglected, they will leave for another party in the galaxy.

Will your party be a celestial success? Or will you find yourself alone with the punch bowl?

name: Warnimal
description: In Warnimals, four animal races battle for supremacy in a fantasy world.

name: Suckerfish Investing Game!
description:
Suckerfish Investing Game is a fun and educational tabletop game that teaches players the important life principles of value investing!

The theme of this game is to not only survive but thrive within the deep sea of investing! This game is named after the smart and cunning “suckerfish” (aka a Remora) that swims alongside sharks and whales in the deep ocean. These fish are not scared of the sharks and the sharks are not bothered by the fish.

They thrive together. The sharks catch big fish and the Remora eat up all the scraps! Then the Remora suction-cup their heads to the sharks (which remove any barnacles from the shark) in order to catch a free ride on the shark as it swims through the vast ocean.

These suckerfish have a pretty good deal!

In Suckerfish Investing players will follow alongside a whale and a shark as they rise and fall (in price) throughout the deep sea of investing! Players will learn the mental side of investing, such as buying low, selling high and collecting dividends. Likewise, players will learn the emotional side of investing, such as not freaking out, being patient and investing for the long term.

In this game, players will start with $5,000 each and then receive an additional $2,000 contribution every couple of months. Each player will receive the same amount throughout the game, and it is their job to invest it wisely to WIN!

This game consists of a deck of 44 playing cards, 8 player cards, and 2 company cards. Each company card has 26 tiles that represent units of stock, and each company has an electronic tally counter (2 total) that keep track of the price of each company as it moves. Each card (labeled NEXT MONTH) represents 1 month of time and the entire deck represents an investing journey of over 3 years!

Once the game is setup and all players are ready, the game begins and players may buy Fast Growth or Blue Chip in increments of 100 shares. Players do not have “turns” in this game, rather, they can buy and or sell at any time and must help each other to double-check the math and accounting.

When all players are ready, one player can flip the NEXT MONTH card on the top of the deck and follow its instructions to either:
Update the numbers on the electronic tally counters by pressing the red or green buttons
Distribute contributions to the player whose color matches the color on the card
Pay dividends to all players who own the dividend paying company
All players pay taxes when these cards arise

Throughout this game, players have to keep track of two moving stock prices while deciding whether to buy, sell, hold or wait, and this game is an emotional rollercoaster ride of investing!

Players will continue this throughout the entire deck of cards. When the last card is played, the player with the highest score WINS! (Fast Growth + Blue Chip + Cash = Total Score)

This game teaches players:
1. Multiplication, addition, and subtraction
2. Accounting of money and stock units
3. Investing principle - buy low and sell high
4. Investing principle - collect and reinvest dividends
5. Emotional intelligence - don’t let your emotions lead you to bad investing such as buying when the price goes up and then watching it go down, rather than watching it go down and then buying!
6. Advanced strategy - keeping track of the spread and standard deviation between the two companies to take advantage (buy and sell) of opportunities in price swing
7. Advanced strategy - recognizing the patterns and building an investment strategy to take advantage of these growth and dividend payments patterns

About the Two Companies:

Fast Growth - a fast-growing company whose price is up and down and all over the place. You can make a lot of money with Fast Growth if you buy it at the right time. Buy low and sell high! *Fast Growth does not pay dividends.

Blue Chip ETF - a whole bunch of individual companies rolled into one “exchange-traded fund” or ETF. This stock will grow a bit slower than Fast Growth, but it pays big dividends!

Each player may buy or sell either Fast Growth or Blue Chip in increments of 100 with a limit of 500 per month. The player with the highest score at the end of the card deck is the WINNER!

“I created this game because I truly wish I had this game when growing up. I didn’t learn about this basic investing stuff until my 30’s and I definitely wasn’t able to cram 3 years of investing experience into 30 minutes! I believe this game can help educate and inspire a generation to become financially free!”

Josh Vojtisek
Game creator
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Economic, Electronic, Math, Number, Party Game
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Simulation, Stock Holding, Trading, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Phase Order

name: RÃ¶sselsprung
description:
The players have to move their four tokens from their red starting spaces to the starting spaces on the opposite side on the game board. Movement is one knight's move (as in Chess) per turn.

If only 2 players are playing, only the part of the game board inside the red borders is used.

If 3 or 4 players are playing, 2 token of each player have to pass the right side of the game board center, while the other 2 pass on the left side.

If a player has the opportunity to beat an opponent token by landing on the same space, he has to do so. The beaten token is returned to it's starting space and has to begin anew.

—user summary

name: Titanomachina
description:
Titanomachina is crunchy giant robot action! Players bring customized strategies (Titans composed of systems, weapons, and crews; and buildings) to battle their opponents for local supremacy. Position and timing are crucial, as weapons charge, initiative changes hands, and the cease-fire deadline inches closer.

Before the first round players draw cards for initiative, and can either set up by using a system of points, or by drafting their Titan's systems, weapons and crew out of the available cards. After set-up, the players add the weapon and crew cards to their decks of systems. Players can order these decks to their liking. Finally, players place their buildings and then their Titans on the board.

During a round players take turns in order of highest initiative score to lowest. Each turn a player can either play cards from their hand; they can play ('activate') one card face-up as an action, and others face-down to charge it, or pass. Actions include moving, attacking, blocking attacks, generating shields, repairing the Titan, increasing a Titan's initiative score (and changing its player's position in the turn order), and using crew to operate weapons for bonuses. Players keep taking turns until they run out of cards or they all pass. When the round is over all played cards are discarded to the bottom of their Titan decks, and players draw more cards from the top of those decks.

The game lasts 18 rounds, or until one player achieves a 10-point lead on their respective scores. Buildings determine the player's starting score. Players then score additional Victory Points by destroying parts of enemy Titans, and preserving their own Titan until the end of the game. Players need to manage all the parts of their titanic machines to turn them into smoothly running engines of victory.

-description from designer
categories: City Building, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Deck Construction, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Movement Points, Square Grid, Sudden Death Ending, Tile Placement, Turn Order: Stat-Based

name: Royal Cup: Icebreaker
description:
There are two versions of this game:
Royal Cup Icebreaker (the regular version) & Royal Cup Firemaker (the adult, NSFW version)

This is a strategic game designed to help shy, reserved and otherwise introverted people break the metaphorical ice, come out of their shells, get out of their comfort zones and let loose. It is similar to King's Cup but IT ISN'T King's Cup (we cannot stress this enough).

The game works like this: players take turns picking cards and responding to the actions on the cards, you could pick cards like Licktator, Royal Interrogator, Queen of Hearts, Secrets and many more. The objective of the game is to play your friends, making them share as much as humanly possible about their deepest darkest secrets. Players continue picking cards and fulfilling its actions until either the chain of cards is broken--which results in that player being kicked out of the game--or a Licktator takes a player out, immediately ending their Licktatorship. The last player remaining in the game, wins.

The game is a lot of fun, has a lot of elements from traditional games such as spin the bottle, never have I ever, truth or dare and other games, and it has a lot of hilarious rules such as No Cursing, Hodor!, CPR, Eunuch, Premature Pants/Long Live the King and many more.

The game is available in four languages (English, German, Spanish and Persian).

—description from the designer

name: The Armoury Bible Game
description:
In the world of The Armoury, you will work together to battle sin by forging and putting on the Armour of God!

Use The Armoury Bible Game to teach the Bible to friends and family as the Game Master or learn the Bible by adventuring in the game as the Warrior or Bard.

As a player your team will do various Bible challenges such as memorising scripture, answering Bible questions and finding Bible books you will score Attack, Defence or Utility points to engage the Tentacled Creature of Disparage (Sin) in battle.

As the Game Master, you will customise the Attack, Defence and Utility challenges in order to maximise your Bible learning!

Once the team have successfully defeated the devilish Tentacled Creature of Disparage you will be awarded real-life Quests by the Game Master to continue the epic adventure and Bible learning away from the table.

The Armoury Bible Game can be used to teach apologetics, catechise and encourage daily Bible reading.

—description from the publisher

name: End the Outbreak
description:
End the Outbreak is a 1-4 Player Table Top Board Game, Players are the Heroes on a mission to Quarantine a worldwide outbreak, along the way they must battle hoards of zombies, multiple mini-bosses and defeat the 3 main bosses guarding the components needed to quarantine the outbreak.

Using Perks to gain advantage over stronger enemy mini-bosses, players must make their way through the game collecting XP required to face the main bosses before they buy the ending and End the Outbreak.

A feature rich roll and play Zombie themed board game.

—description from the designer

name: Forgotten Floof
description:
Forgotten Floof is a competitive resource management and civilization building card game for 2-5 players.

Cast out by man in the wake of internet pug memes, nyan cats and doge, the once beloved (but now forgotten) guinea pigs of the world must look to build a new future for themselves.

Each player starts as leader of a faction of 30 outcast guinea pigs all looking for a home. Your aim is to end the game with the most sheltered guinea pigs, hence becoming the most prosperous tribe.

To build shelters, players require resources. At the start of each round a number of resources are played to the centre of the table. Players mark the ones they wish to claim using their 3 action tokens and subsequently compete over them using their guinea pigs. The strongest guinea pig takes the spoils whilst the others are sent to the graveyard.

Resources such as wood, rope, cloth and stone can be traded in to construct buildings.

Each type of building allows the player to provide shelter for a number of their guinea pigs. Additionally, hospitals allow you to revive those injured in battle, prisons can be used to capture enemy guinea pigs, mines generate free resources each round and temples award powerful miracle cards.

At the end of each round players will see a number of their homeless guinea pigs succumb to a terrible catastrophe such as a comet strike, or being eaten by a fat cat - only those safely sheltered inside a building are safe. Eventually when there are no more homeless guinea pigs the game is over and only the player with the most sheltered floof will be declared the winner.

—description from the publisher

name: Royal Cup: Firemaker
description:
This is the adult, NSFW version of Royal Cup: Icebreaker-- a social card game for parties designed to help people of all walks of life come out of their shells, break out of their comfort zones, let loose and break the metaphorical ice. Royal Cup: Firemaker is for ages 17 and up, is like King's Cup on steroids without actually being a drinking game. The game's premise is not about drinking, rather about making you get to know your friends on a level you never knew them before or by getting to know complete strangers on a personal, intimate, and human level by asking the right (and wrong) questions. Every aspect of the game was designed with one overarching question in mind: does this help break the ice? It's primarily designed to help shy, reserved and introverted people socialize, laugh their socks off, and have a great time.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Singing, Storytelling, Voting

name: Face to Face
description:
OUR KICKSTARTER CAMPAIGN BEGINS NOVEMBER 5! COME SUPPORT US!

Something has gone very wrong with the world! Animals have been separated from the places they belong - can you help put them back?

In the card game Face to Face, players work to match animal halves and return them to their respective habitats. The game contains 4 different habitats (arctic, jungle, savannah, and pasture); each habitat has 4 different animals available.

The game begins with two shuffled decks of cards - "Place" cards and "Face" cards. These are placed where all players can reach them. The player who has had the most exotic pet goes first. On his/her turn, each player can select a maximum of 2 of the following actions: (1) take a card from either deck; (2) put a card down; (3) trade a card with another player; (4) discard a card; or (5) pass. Players' hands may not exceed 7 cards.

Players get points for the matched pairs they place down on the animals' correct habitats. First player to 10 points wins.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Environmental

name: Fruit Flip!
description:
Fruit Flip is a bright color matching, hex-card flipping game of memory, strategy, and sabotage. On their turn, each player places a card from their hand following placement rules. After playing your card, flip all adjacent cards. Keep as many of your chosen fruit face up by the end of the game, while flipping your opponent's fruit down. At the end of the game the player with the highest number of their fruit WINS the game!

Plays in 2 Modes!

Basic Fruit Flip!
Enjoy this slower, relaxed version of the game encouraging more strategy and sabotage. This version can be enjoyed with 2-6 players. Great for in between long difficult games, bar game, used in classrooms! Appropriate ages start at 6 but great for all ages and type of gamer.

Multiplayer Death Match
Pick up the pace with this exciting card-dropping version of Fruit Flip! 2 teams, 2 decks, facing off against each other to place their cards first. Only the team that plays all of their cards first will get to determine the winner of the game!

—description from the publisher

name: AGGRO: 70's Football Skirmish Rules
description:
It's a violent time, bands of men bent on destruction march the land under their colours, bringing fear and violence to towns and Cities across the land.

Yes it's the 1970's and gangs from across the country come together using local football allegiances as excuses to have a right royal rumble with each other.

AGGRO provides a set of rules that gives you the opportunity to pit rival gangs against one another in a time when the only things tighter than a professional footballers perms were the shorts he wore on match day.

The rules take a tongue in cheek look at the 70's and have been put together so friends can spend an hour or two taunting one another.

Goal of the game is getting more street cred than the other firm, singing, throwing and bashing against them. Your firm can win by drawing the right playing cards, but your opponent also draws cards to mitigate the effect. Taking turn is eas: alternating, but your opponents action requires a counter actions. Then there are instants changing the gameply, e.g. a traffic warden, who is a source of distraction, as wellas bobby's or a streaker running across the feld.

Just put a firm together and....

—description from the publisher

name: Supercards: PerÃº CampeÃ³n
description:
Supercards is a football card game for 2 players (with an additional solitaire mode). Each player holds five hand cards and tries to form effective combos which enable them to shoot at the opponents goal. The opponent can use block or counterattack cards, but since hands are refilled at the beginning of a turn, one can try to attack when the opponent is low on cards to maximize one's chances. Some special cards simulate fan support and specially gifted players.
There is a game end card somewhere in the bottom half of the draw pile. When that appears, each player has another two turns before the final whistle sounds. Whoever scored more goals, wins.

In the solitaire mode, the player plays their way through a world cup with group and knock out stages. The opponent is randomized with a simple system.

name: Oddassity Party Game
description:
Oddassity is a social party game of improv style actions. Oddassity is made up of three decks of increasingly absurd dares, plus a fourth deck that plays like Russian roulette. Players take turns flipping Play Cards to determine if an ODDASSITY Card will be performed. The object of the game is to deliver the best performances as determined by the group.

A group of 4 or more players decide the ODDASSITY level your party can handle by picking 1-3 ODDASSITY Decks between NSFP (Not Safe For Prudes), NC (Needs Consent) and R (Racy), or customize their own deck. ODDASSITY CARDS are shuffled, flipped, and read out loud. The player who will obey the ODDASSITY is determined by the Play Cards.

Players take turns flipping Play Cards. There are four types of Play Cards:
YAY!- Player will obey the ODDASSITY Card
NEIGH!- No one obeys the ODDASSITY Card
FLIP!- Discard the current ODDASSITY Card, flip a new one
SAVE AN ASS!- Save yourself or another player from the ODDASSITY

Once the Play deck is exhausted, the group decides which player gave the best performances of the game.

name: Executive Order
description:
You're a fresh Commander-In-Chief spending your first day in The Oval Office. There are a million promises you need to keep that you made on the campaign trail, but there's one that echoes through those who've supported you: build the wall. The only problem is there are those who want to do it before you and take all your glory. But you can't let that happen, you're the greatest! Nobody is better than you.
Executive Order is a game of quickness and trolling as you fight to complete your wall before your competitors. But will you go straight for the glory and complete your wall? Or will you instead make it as difficult as possible for your competitors to complete theirs?

Use cards to create strategic moves and shuffle things around. Don’t like your current hand? Play “Alternative Facts” and draw a new one. Somebody put down a Wall card before you? Play “Congress” to have it taken away.

Ideal for 2-7 players 13 and over. Gameplay averages 30 minutes or more.

In Executive Order, the goal for players is to be the first to have three active Wall cards in front of them on the table. Players take turns by playing a card from their hand, resolving its action, and then drawing back up to their hand size. Some cards that can be played include "Wall" cards, "Budget Cuts" (reduces a players hand size by one card), "Congress" (removes an active wall card from in front of a player), "Deport" (cancels a players card and returns it to their hand), or "Umm, No!" (cancels a players turn). Players can even debate on the table by creating a stack of "Deports" and "Ummm, Nos" until someone claims victory!

Players can also add new rules by playing the "Executive Order" card. But be careful, a "Court Ruling" card can put your rule to a vote to see if it remains or a player can play "AltTwit@ExeOrder" to exempt themselves from the rule!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Political

name: The Grid: AI Awakens
description:
With no two games ever the same, The Grid is a dynamic card-driven game for 2 to 4 players set around one of the most intriguing, disruptive and unnerving breakthroughs of the 21st century: self-aware Artificial Intelligence.

As a world-leading scientist, you race your fellow researchers to take control of the Grid: a set of technological pillars that once discovered, will lead to the first true AI.

Yet, you do not only compete with others. In an unusual twist, you also face off against a fledgling, rapidly-evolving AI who also seeks to command the Grid - the very parts that make up its being.

To take on The Grid, you’ll research 12 critical technologies like robotics and cognitive science, protect them from AI attack with firewalls, manipulate The Grid to claim a strategic advantage, or reclaim a pillar overrun by the awakening artificial force.

In your mission to harness AI, you’ll use Development cards to give you research-enabling brain power or influence. But your fate is not entirely in your hands; progress will continually be shaped by Contingencies that reveal unexpected traits within yourself, deliver useful power-ups to accelerate research or introduce game-changing events - such as AI Attack - that can instantly change the balance of power.

The path to AI supremacy is clear. Collect tech and victory tokens as you research technology pillars, or overtake them from opposing forces. Complete critical secret missions that strengthen your claim of AI control. Once the Grid is fully developed, the scientist with the most points has won, unlocking the infinite potential of AI for all of humanity.

But be careful not to focus too much on the scientific rivalry. The juvenile AI also seeks control of The Grid. When the time comes, put aside differences and work together to repel it… or risk giving this artificial force the power to escape into the world and confront mankind with an uncertain future.

When you set out to master The Grid, you do so with numerous decks of exquisite cards and tokens that have been carefully crafted to immerse you in a futuristic frontier of self-aware intelligence.

Fight to harness the phenomenal power of The Grid. But be sure to control it… or it will control you.
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Modular Board, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: 7th Voyage: The Witching Hour
description:
Inspired by the folklore and tales of gothic horror, you take command of the heroes or villians of legend! The Witching Hour is written entirely by Glenn Allan, and presented by Crooked Dice.

Send the Headless Horseman back to the depths of hell or command the gruesome witch-hunts from the dark days of history with this new 7th Voyage gothic horror supplement. You will need a copy of the 7th Voyage rules to use this product.

The Witching Hour adds new stars, co-stars and extras profiles, as well as new scenarios, Gifts of the Gods and Events.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Mythology

name: 4 Armies
description:
Items needed:

1 deck standard playing cards
Two 6-sided dice


Gameplay:
Each player will choose one suit of cards as their army then roll the die to determine who has the first turn. Each player then draws 3 cards from his deck and places his remaining cards aside. The person to win the first turn of the first round chooses an opponent from among the remaining players. To attack, he lays down one of his three chosen cards. The chosen opponent also lays down one of his three chosen cards.(Right before each player lays down his attacking card,it is best to snap the attacking card out of one’s own hand in a showy and extravagant manner. This is done to intimidate the other player. It is also quite enjoyable.)To determine the winner of the attack, each player must roll a die, combine that number with the value of his card, and whomever has the highest overall score wins the battle. Each number card is worth its face value (the Ace is worth 1 point, the 2 is worth 2 points, etc,), and each face card is worth 10 points. However, when attacking with a Jack, the Jack gains one offensive point becoming worth 11 points, and when defending with a Queen, the Queen gains 1 defensive point becoming worth 11 points. If a tie takes place, the defender wins the round. Play continues in clock-wise fashion with each player attacking only once each round. If a player has no cards when it is his turn to attack, then he is out for the remainder of the round.

Each successive round is begun by the person clock-wise from the person to attack first in the previous round.

The winner of the game is determined by the player with the last King left alive. If a player loses a King during game play, he may continue playing but cannot win the game.

Suit powers

Hearts: Healers. At the end of each turn roll 1 die for any one card that fought during that turn. If the roll is odd, healing failed and proceed to next card or end turn. If even, roll die and regain health up to number rolled or max health (whichever comes first)

Spades: Necromancers. At the end of each turn, if any cards 1-6 “died" during that turn or in a previous turn they are eligible to be revived. Roll a die and revive any eligible card covered by the die. Example: If a 1 is rolled then an the ace (if eligible) can be revived. If a 5 is rolled, any card 1-5 that is eligible can be revived.

Diamonds: +Defense every card. +1 health and 50/50 chance to “block” an attack by rolling die when attacked. If even, a "block" happens and negates an additional damage point.

Clubs: +Offense every card. +1 to attack roll and 50/50 chance to do “double damage” on an attack by rolling die when attacking. If even, a "double damage" happens and adds an additional damage point.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: é³¥ç£æ¼«ç» (Tyouju-Manga)
description:
User summary
é³¥ç£æ¼«ç» (Tyouju-Manga), is a Japanese card game, a quick 'communications' game using cards. The artwork on the cards is taken from classic Japanese painting. Animals are shown as if human, and they play out folklore tales, frogs, rabbits, birds, and foxes. This gives the game a light, surreal feeling.

In this game, all players try to make a manga. Players start with a certain number of cards in hand. These cards act as a single frame with an empty dialogue balloon. In clockwise order, the active player plays a card and all players discuss about what quote should be included in the dialogue balloon. A new card played acts as a continuing frame from the previous cards so all players will attempt to make a totally original manga with an original story.

Publisher's summary
