Use a dictator to play an evil action card from your hand and deal damage to other dictators or old ladies.
Use an old lady to play a good action card from your hand and either deal damage to other dictators or heal an old lady.
Use any of your character's special skills.

You can use the unicorn cards in your hand at any single moment of the game – during your turn or during your opponent’s turn – in order to affect the gameplay in endless unexpected ways.

Will you be Saddam, or Miss Husain? Will you send Nazi zombies to eat your opponent’s brains or defeat them by giving them cute puppy presents which will destroy their evil dignity Witness a Third World War like no other, fought with poo mines and cotton candy, and rainbow vomit all over the place.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Puppy Poo!
description:
18-card mini-game.
Mechanics: take-that, hand management, player-elimination.

A single pack of 18 plays 2-4 players...but adding more packs expands player count, all the way up to an unlimited number of players (recommended 12 max) making it a party game. 3 packs play up to 12.

Deck contains 2 (per pack being used) of POO! cards, catch another player with one in their hand, and they are out. Last player standing gets match-point. First to 3 (or agreed to larger number for a longer game) wins. Use attack cards to accuse, defense cards to survive, shifting cards to move POO! to other players.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Martial Cards
description:
Martial Cards is a fun and quick card game inspired by martial arts, video games, and movies of the 80’s and 90’s. In this two-player, turn-based, hand management style fighting card game, players will pick a character deck and challenge their friends to a martial arts match. Players take turns executing attacks and enhancements until one of them is reduced to zero life and the other is standing as victor!

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Video Game Theme

name: Yu-Gi-Oh! TCG: Structure Deck â Powercode Link
description:
This is the 42nd Deck in the TCG's Structure Deck series.

Create brand new Link Summoning combinations with Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Structure Deck: Powercode Link! This Deck features a new “Code Talker” Link Monster plus LINK-2 and LINK-3 monsters you can Summon using any monsters, and whose Link Arrows all point to your own Main Monster Zones!

Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Structure Deck: Powercode Link is a great second step for Duelists who started Dueling with Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Starter Deck: Codebreaker. Co-Link your Transcode Talker from Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Starter Deck: Codebreaker with Powercode Talker to boost both monsters by 500 ATK and make them untargetable by opposing card effects! The added protection helps keep Powercode Talker ready to make double-powered attacks every turn.

Finally, for Duelists that like to live dangerously, a new Field Spell gives you a chance to Special Summon a random Cyberse-Type Link Monster directly from your Extra Deck without having to Link Summon or use any monsters as Materials. But to claim that reward, you have to take 2000 or more damage from one battle or card effect, simulating Playmaker’s “Storm Access” skill from the animated series!


Each Structure Deck contains:


38 Common Cards, 2 Ultra Rare Cards, 3 Super Rare Cards, 1 Beginner‘s Guide and 1 Double-sided Deluxe Game Mat/Dueling Guide


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: MON: Anarchy Phantasy Multi Card Game
description:
A card deck that can be used in many ways. Can even be used as dice.

54 cards + 2 rule cards forms a deck of 56 cards. The deck can be used as normal playing cards from 2 to ace + jokers. But also as a Japanese Hanafuda deck (48 cards + 6 jokers). The cards can be used playing Trumps, Dingo, Old Maid and other games also.

You can also battle with the characters. Pick five random cards each and do not show your opponent. The rest of the cards is placed in a “dice pile”. The player who most recently was in a fight (for real!) start. It might be back in preschool? Pick one of your characters and decide if you want to do a physical attack; the sword or a mental attack; the candle. Sword attacks are obviously defended by the shield and candle attacks are defended by the smiley face; humour.

The opponent picks out a character he thinks can defend without knowing the attacking value. Now both player draws a card from the dice pile and add the eyes on the card's die to their value, starting with the attacker. Highest total wins and is placed in front of the winner as a used character that won the battle. Also place the die card under it, it's the price for winning; a new recruit. The defeated character is placed in bottom of the dice pile (face up) and the die card (face down).

For example: player one (Kajsa) gets Lonar, Cadran, Minx, Dag and Moog. She chooses Lonar, one of the most powerful characters in the game and attacks with brains/candle (value 8). Player two (Kalle) chooses to defend with his character with highest humour, but that is still only Silver (5). Kajsa takes the first card in the dice pile which is Ulg. Ulg has however only 1 eye on his T6. 8 + 1 = 9 in mental attack. Kalle draws the next card and gets Donolen who has 5 eyes on the T6. 5 + 5 = 10. Silver wins and is placed in front of Kalle along with Donolen. They are now battle weary and not available until everybody have fought. Kajsa's Lonar is discarded under the dice pile along with Ulg. But defeated cards like Lonar can return as an undead and is placed face up! Ulg is placed face down like all other cards. Kalle wins the battle and starts the next round.

If the numbers are even the result is a tie, place both characters in front of the players, they are also battle weary and not available. However the dice cards are discarded and not won. Continue battling until all characters have fought. If both players have character cards left after everybody has fought, pick them up again and repeat everything. Shuffle the dice pile again and remember to keep the undead face up. The one with the least cards start the next battle. If even use rock-papers-scissors to decide. If an undead gets into your army keep it upside down on your hand. When played it automatically defeats both the opponent and him/herself. Remove the undead from the game after battle. The loser is the player who lost all of his/her cards. If one player has more characters to play than the other those are rested until next round.

Try adding rules like that darker cards have +1 against lighter cards or that same silhouettes can’t fight each other for example.

—description from the publisher

name: Grab the Mike, the "Worlds Greatest Karaoke Style" Board Game
description:
You think you know music? You think you can recognize songs faster than your friends? Then prove it and Grab the Mike! The only game that tests your music knowledge, reaction time and singing ability (or lack thereof)! Cards are drawn to select music genres; whatever genre is revealed is then played on your favorite streaming radio app or played on your smart home speaker. Once the song starts, the first person that recognizes the song Grabs the Mike and attempts to sing at least the first two lines of the song correctly. Know more than the first two lines? Then keep singing for more points. The rest of the group judges you on how well you know the song and awards points accordingly. Or, use a pass chip and make any other player attempt said song. In the deck there are also spoiler cards, where you may have to sing a duet or the whole group may have to get up and sing as a choir. Fast-paced, addictive party game that is fun for all ages!

—description from the publisher

name: Capes & Chaos: Strategy Card Game
description:
Capes & Chaos is an all new story universe of Superheroes and Master Villains brought to you by 2C Comics and designer Dan Hopkins. Set in the not too distant future of current day earth, devastated after an apocalyptic attack of aliens and demons, the grand opening of the Capes & Chaos universe is revealed through this, the strategy card game. Included right out of the box are two full stand-alone versions, Basic Edition and Advanced Edition. Basic Edition plays as a "medium-weight board game" with fresh mechanics, and over 140 unique works of high quality art! Continuing right on top of Basic Edition, adding depth and enhancing strategy, Advanced Edition dives deeper into a "dueling style" card game, but with a twist! In Capes & Chaos, while you are still competing against other players, you do not go head-to-head. Instead you will fight neutral opponents in a compelling mix of both new concepts and traditional elements of combat from tabletop RPGs. Capes & Chaos is sure to deliver hours of hobby fun!

In Capes & Chaos: Strategy Card Game you are taking on the role of a "Titan", the most powerful of superhuman heroes. Your deck of cards represents your superpowers and military assets for protecting your people and fighting against the overwhelming chaos threatening what little remains of civilization. As part of a larger effort to protect the last bastions of society, Titans fight to defeat enemies and complete missions on the battlefield. In order to promote greater success, a friendly competition has ensued among the Titans. Who can defeat the most dangerous foes while completing their missions the fastest? Race against your fellow Titans to accumulate the most Threat Points!

As a Titan you will play with a constructed deck of "Cape Cards" and fight against a random assortment of "Chaos Cards" as the opposition of the game. Cape Cards do not have common card backs, each side is unique. One side shows the card's art, the other side shows the card's abilities. Basic Edition only uses the art side of the card, where as Advanced Edition uses both sides of the card.

There are no rule variations between Advanced Edition and Basic. Advanced builds right on top of Basic Edition by adding additional rules. Therefore Basic is either a stepping stone to Advanced and must be learned first, or a separate game to be enjoyed on its own merits.

Game length varies as the number of rounds to complete a game is determined by the players at the start of each game. At the end of the game, accumulated Threat Points are tallied to determine winner placements.

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Christmas Miss Givings
description:
A fun family friendly game for 4-8 players, ages 10 and up.
It’s Christmas Eve, and you’ve all forgotten to get each other gifts! Now you’ve got a few hours left before the store closes to rush and get some gifts that (hopefully) match each other’s interests and score some points. The most points at the end of the game wins. Just watch out for people being Naughty!

Everyone gets 3 unique interest cards at the start of the game, as well as some fit cards to get started. Each gift has two interest on it, including a few double interest cards, ad each round, players will have to give out a gift. Each match is worth 2 points, and a self match is 1 point.

And then there are Naughty or Nice cards. Naughty cards to things like steal cards and swap gifts, while Nice cards help out the other players, but score 1 point. There are also Block cards, which will stop the other Naughty and Nice cards, and can score points if used to block Naughty cards.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Harem Wars: Army Gals Add-on Pack
description: Add on deck of unique cards for Harem Wars. Contained 50 cards.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Mature / Adult

name: Fright House
description:
Build and run your own haunted house in this worker placement/tile placing hybrid game.

Get together with up to three of your friends and compete to see who can build the best and scariest haunted house and frighten the most guests without accidentally scaring them to death. There's plenty of player interaction as you can connect your houses up to theirs, swap guests from their queues to yours, raise and lower the fear level of various guests with effects cards - all to keep players on their toes and ruin the most well laid of plans.

Your workers can head into town to research new house tiles, recruit more workers, promote their house and attract guests, or collect the necessary resources to build their house.

The workers also double as scarers! They can head into the house to help scare guests in the correct directions or they can work the queue at the front-of-house to prime guests for a more frightening experience. But be careful! Many guests have special attributes that can throw a wrench in things like "Screamer" - this guest will raise the fear level of every adjacent guest when they become scared! Use these different abilities to play guests off one another or interrupt other player's plans.

The only way to get cash is by admitting people to your house, they pay the second they come in whether they have a good time or not. As a guest enters, you'll slot them into a standee base with a rotating dial to track their fear level.

If guests have a good time, you can invite them to come back. If guests die, they take up precious storage bays and prevent you from storing the necessary resources to build up your house. If you kill too many guests, it means a change of management and a huge loss of points.

The gameplay goes on a night-by-night basis for 7 days leading up to halloween, resetting and paying workers at the end of each night. As the game wraps up after all the guests leave on Halloween night, Euro-style rules kick in and players reveal secret values each of their successfully scared guests contribute to their total score.

Spook House is a complex game with multiple strategies to win, currently clocking in around 3 hours for a full playthrough with four players. But it's still very early in development.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Take That, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Martian Slayers
description:
After a dark decade of pirating and pillage, the Solar Federation has managed to locate the base of the dreaded Vropt in the vicinity of Mars. With the loyalist forces decimated, the mission to cleanse the pirate menace has been entrusted to a small squadron of four aces: former living legends now turned bounty hunters.

Martian Slayers is a free Print-and-Play cardgame that reproduces a 16-bit shmup videogame from the 90s era! Each player takes control of a ship with 3 lives, 2 or 3 bombs, and some Maneuvers. You are supposed to kill as many enemies as possible while minimizing the incoming fire, because any hit will make our ship explode.

—description from the designer
categories: Print & Play, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Jazzy Pips
description:
Jazzy Pips is a quick, cooperative dice game played in real-time for 3 to 6 players.

You’ve just formed a jazz band! It won’t be easy though. You know your instrument well, but you need to get to know the other musicians you’re playing with. This is the fun of joining a band! With practice, coordination, and the right tempo, you’ll be pulling off a memorable set at the local club in no time!

In Jazzy Pips, each player, or Musician, must work together to overcome Song Cards by using your dice and making quick decisions at the same time. If you complete the Finale, you win! Be careful though, as the clock is ticking, and your dice are limited!

—description from the designer

name: Mgbako
description: Mgbako (means ‘to calculate’ in Igbo language) is a speed arithetic Boardgame made in Nigeria. Players compete to earn points by beating their opponent in simple arithmetic. It’s not as simple as it sounds. Try winning when the stakes are up and tensions are high.

name: Oyyaa
description: Oya is a game designed based on the life of a Lagosian (someone who lives in Lagos Nigeria). It explores the Olokpa (police), the JJCs, The Area Boys and hustlers alike. It’s a fast-paced game.

name: Ukubuwa
description:
UKUBUWA is a misspelt Swahili word for ‘Greatness’, and it takes you through a journey of young people as you earn and lose wealth. , Ukubuwa is a game that takes you through the four stages of life in your perspective.
It starts with the Learning stage (things that affect you in this stage), then takes you to the Idea stage (Talent Development), the Philanthropy level. The interesting thing is that it brings choice and chance to play – chance because you have to roll dice and play, choice because you have to make decisions. It was designed basically for storytelling. While playing, you gain certain things like how to negotiate, how to spend money. It’s the mechanism. Overall, it’s a game of choice and chance.

name: SteamPunk Arena
description:
Somewhere in a dark but distant future, humankind is fighting a war for survival against its greatest threat - a changing climate. The polar ice caps have melted, entire civilizations, swept away almost overnight. A distant rust-covered memory, the world we knew has been swallowed whole, lost in the murky depths of an unforgiving ocean.

Desperate, starving, and lacking the technical achievements of a forgotten era, the surviving population propels steam-powered engines towards the farthest corners of earth in search of the faintest glimmer of hope. Some found this hope on a plot of ocean simply known as the Arena. Through uncharted waters, there lies a thousand islands eroded by time, where untold riches await to be discovered by the remnants of past civilizations. You are among the desperate few in search of those lost treasures.

SteamPunk Arena is a turn-based strategy game with an objective to explore the islands looking for salvage, exploit the resources you find there, expand your domain using bridge networks, and exterminate your opponent. In SteamPunk Arena, each combatant chooses a faction, and then chooses the hero who will lead that faction into battle. These heroes will help spur theatre-specific units on by providing an action modifying bonus.

The combatants begin the conflict with the same garrisoned unit strength and an equal amount of land; however, this is where your similarities will end. Where you place your Base Tile or Land Tiles is entirely up to you. What lies hidden and waiting to be discovered could also provide a unique advantage or disadvantage. But keep in mind no matter what your path looks like, the dice-roll will often decide the outcome of events that transpire throughout the playthrough.

Using a turn-based unit action system. The combatant controls the action of active units throughout the duration of the turn until all action points are spent. The health of the unit is determined by a population or hit-point, found in the center of the piece. Units can only be deployed one per turn. There are only so many population points you can have active on the arena game boards at any given time, unless modified by a certain Resource or Unit Bonus. So choose your army wisely and enjoy the fight. We will see you out in the Arena!

name: Tike's Dungeon
description:
Tike’s Dungeon can be played as a solo adventure or as a 2-4 player co-op. Above that, it can be played in two different styles: Turn-based board game where players take turns to explore the crypt and battling creatures and the narrative-driven role-playing game (RPG). In both styles of play, the players will take on the role of a Tike and are highly encouraged to interact with and help each other.

"Raivynwood is a small but prosperous village nestled neatly in the, get this, Raivynwood forest. It is most well known for its local militia which is comprised of some of the most well-trained soldiers in the land. But it has another, rather unfortunate, claim to fame which is a little less known, and that is that Raivynwood is a hub of catastrophe. If anything can go wrong, anything in the world, it will go wrong in Raivynwood. That may be the reason for needing such well-trained men and women, or that could just be a coincidence.
The training in Raivynwood starts at the ripe age of 5, these boys and girls are called the CIC (Combat Initiative Cubs). They mostly play with sticks and wooden shields in childish games that have a fortunate side-effect of teaching them how to kick butt. The Cubs graduate at the age of 7 when they become CIBs (Combat Initiative Bloomer). CIBs practice with dull metal weapons, begin to learn the bow and learn the value of respecting and helping their parents. It’s an important lesson, you know? Finally, at the harsh age of 11, Bloomers get promoted to the Raivynwood CIA (Combat Initiative Adepts). As a junior member of the Raivynwood CIA it is your duty to train hard and watch over your small piece of paradise when the grownups aren’t around.
On this day, of all days… the day on which the grownups have all gone to the eastern forest edge to confront a new lizardfolk threat… misfortune has stricken. As you and your fellow CIA members train in the city square, showing off your moves and flirting with your crush, you are disrupted…"

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: SoundTrax
description:
''SoundTrax is the newest party game for party people. The game is simple. Each round, a director sets the scene by reading a Soundtrax card aloud, and everyone else answers with the funniest or most accurate song that best suits the scene.

When your song is voted winner of the round, you collect the Soundtrax Card. The first player to collect 3 Soundtrax Cards earns the prestigious Soundtrax Award of Best Director in a Party Role!

—description from the publisher

name: Everworld
description:
Everworld is a narrative, tactical combat RPG for 2-4 players with an emphasis on moral decisions and story development of the characters. It is based on a fantasy setting where high magic is forbidden and heroes have been forgotten.

Heroes play against the game system, using AI decks for enemies and 9 skill cards for their turns. They have also to bet for results when resolving events and taking moral decisions. They win if they achieve each mission objectives, and they lose if they all fall exhaust.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Book, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Medieval, Miniatures, Novel-based
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Police Board Game: TOP COP
description:
Do you think you have the reflexes, stamina and mental fortitude to be the top of the city’s finest?

In The POLICE Board Game – TOP COP, 2 to 6 players take on the role of patrol officers striving for the title of “Top Cop”. Try to keep the streets of the city safe from crimes (labeled as "PERPs") that Dispatch will identify throughout the five sectors of the map. Players take turns patrolling the city attempting to stop crimes by taking on three different types of challenges (Driving, Physical, & Verbal), aided by equipment and partners helping to get the job done, all the while juggling the stacks of paperwork that the DA’s Office will need filed to prosecute the criminals. Be careful of getting stuck doing paperwork; because if too many perps get off the board, the city will fall into anarchy and the Mayor’s Office won’t be happy!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Twisted Fate: The card game
description:
Gather your friends and family and choose your characters to beat the odds together in this fate twisting game.
Immersive story, unique mechanics and great visual craft that allows you to create strategies, mess with other players' fates and try to win points accordingly to your Fate Card.

The mechanics are pretty simple:
There are 6 characters, each one with its own ability. Each player will have to draw a Fate Card that will establish their fate during the game, basically, it will tell what cards to keep.

The game has 9 rounds, but it can be disrupted by 2 very awesome cards.
From the deck of cards, there are to be shuffled 3 cards per round to each participant.

Playtime: 10-15 minutes.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Open Drafting, Role Playing, Storytelling, Trading

name: Cleopatra Against the Gods
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Ganjifa Play
description:
Ganjifa playing cards were introduced and popularized by Mughal emperors in the 16th century. It has always been one of the popular card games among Moghul Emperors, Emirs and Maharajas. When it was first established, the cards started spreading to many regions of India in the original form or Hindu form. Nowadays it’s difficult to find a suitable deck to play in India. Only a small handful of artisans located in 2 cities still produce Ganjifa cards.

This is where we come in. Let me introduce you to Ganjifa Play.

In Ganjifa Play, players take turns playing suits, taking tricks, and building temples. Ganjifa Play is a trick-taking, hand management game for 2-4 players. Several chips are randomly drawn from the bag to determine (one round, one square, and one diamond) the highest suite symbol that round, the time of day, and the location.

The Round pawn sets the highest deck in the game for that round. The Raja of this suit goes first.

The Diamond pawn, with the time of day symbol indicates the suit that defines the direction of the game. For example, the player whose Raja matches the chosen time of day makes the toughest decision. Does gameplay go Clockwise or Counterclockwise?

The Square pawn defines the location. The players who Raja matches may exchange two cards of their choice with any two from an opponent’s hand.

Once all cards have been played, players count their tricks to determine the winner that round. The winner places the base of their temple onto the mandala playing field. If a number of players have the same number of tricks, all players are deemed winners that round and should put the first part of their temple on the playing field.

The goal is to be the first player to build a complete temple made up of three parts.

—description from the designer

name: Hexiom
description:
Hexiom is a 2 to 6-player abstract war game that can be played in single or 3 rounds.

Hexiom basic game has no element of luck. Each player's turn consists of the following:

Introduce a new hex tile at various heights with a player's unit on it.
Reinforce an existing hex tile with multiple units.
Transfer units between connected hex tiles.
Attack other players' tiles using simple one-to-one elimination. The height of the hex adds a bonus to the defender.


Winning the game - be the first to complete a row, a ring, or a pyramid of 6 hex tiles controlled by the player.

In the advanced game, Hexiom features optional player perks layered on top of existing gameplay. Each player drafts a single strategy card that is private to them. Each strategic card contains different effects. Players must achieve play conditions specified on the strategic cards to unlock its effects. While strategic cards may only be used once, the hidden advantages for the players extend the experience of the game.

—description from the designer.

name: Dice, Ready, Word
description: Draw a card, choose one of five topics, roll the dice and find matching words for the dice. But be careful: you only have 30 seconds!

name: Kitten Round Up
description:
The kittens need to go to the vet and they need to leave in 10 minutes, but where are they? They're misbehaving and being naughty! The owner needs to round up the kittens and get them to the vet. Mama Cat wants to protect the kittens and put them in her cardboard box. The kittens want to avoid both of them so they can play! The winner is the player who has control of the most kittens at the end of the game.

At the game start there are 9 kittens in the house as well as mama cat and the owner. The owner and mama cat will try each turn to capture one of the kittens and put them in the cat carrier or the cardboard box. The kittens of course, will try to hide or thwart the attempts of the other two. At the game end, whoever controls the most kittens wins. Mama cat controls kittens in the box, the owner controls kittens in the crate and the kitten player controls the kittens that still roam the house.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Take That

name: Kingsfall
description:
Kingsfall is a true 4X campaign style board game with a heavy focus on expansion, resource management, and strategic gameplay. The game was designed for players of all skill and play types as it aims to be streamlined and straight forward. There are no excess mechanics and rules that other 4X style games seem to have, and this allows players to focus on having fun rather than reading rulebooks.

Players each take control of a Guild, and must make their Guild the dominant Guild in the region by whichever means the player chooses. Each Guild has minor perks that may aid a specific play style, but all of the Guilds are on a level playing field. No one Guild is stronger than any others, so choosing your Guild can be a simple as picking your favorite color or name.

Players take turns each moving their pieces around the board, building structures and collecting resources along the way. Heavily dependant on resource management, resources can be used to build more structures and units to increase a player's presence on the map and expand their borders even further. Players must be sure not to grow too quickly however, as in traditional 4X style, everything must be taken care of. People must be fed and paid, and cities must be maintained. Grow too quickly and you won't be able to sustain your empire, grow too slowly and other players will surely beat you to the finish.

With no guidelines restricting player interaction, each of the players is highly encouraged to interact with one another through diplomatic talks. Alliances, war, declaration of friendships, trade, treaties, shunning, the list goes on. Players must bear in mind however the repercussions of their choices and how they may affect other players. With multiple paths to victory, Kingsfall caters to many different play styles. It is entirely possible to win without ever going to war, and it is also possible to win by only going to war. Ultimately the path to victory is up to the player.

Read the back story here
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: PitBulls
description:
Stock exchange simulation game, where the TRADERS watch a 10-round, 8-way contest (among 8 COLORS) and BET/TRADE on the winner of that contest.

The themes are negotiation, probability estimation, and trend-spotting. The goal is to finish with more money than you start with, and even better — finishing with the most money. The mechanism of negotiation is "open outcry" — there are no "turns"; it's everyone's turn at all times to make any deal they can with anyone who is willing to listen to their price(s).

All TRADERS start with a portfolio of 4 shares of each COLOR, plus $400 in cash. As the contest proceeds through 10 rounds, a TRADER use his/her cash to buy COLORS from other TRADERS, and the TRADER will sell shares of his COLORs to raise cash.

The game ends when the 10-round contest is over. At that time the shares of the winning COLOR are worth $100, and the shares of all other COLORs are worth zero. Each TRADER finishes with a total value of his/her portfolio: CASH + SHARES FINISHING "in the money".

PitBulls can be customized to trade on ANY multi-way (up to 8 player/outcome) event or contest. Plus, it's expandable (with more colored (or textured) cards) to trade on ANY event (like the NCAA tournament, presidential election, best performing IPO for the month). If played on a concurrent game of Monopoly, for example, PitBulls becomes a meta game; a session of PitBulls lasts as long as the contest/event on whose outcome you are trading.

—description from designer
categories: Bluffing, Economic, Educational, Math, Negotiation, Party Game
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Commodity Speculation, Negotiation, Pattern Recognition, Push Your Luck, Simulation, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Trevi
description:
Summary
1. Board game , inspired by Trevi Fountain, is a good game for family which uses simple calculation.
2. You have to play ‘fountain cards’ to reach specific ‘lucky number’ and get ‘lucky token’.
3. Recommendations: Ages 8+ (Simple addition and subtraction ability is required.), 2~5 Players, 20~30 Min. to play.

Components
1. Fountain cards: 80 Cards
2. Starting cards: 4 Cards
3. Round cards: 15 Cards
4. Lucky token: 40 Tokens
5. Highest combo card: 1 Card

Preparations
1. Put 4 starting cards on the board side by side. Number ‘7’ is written on starting cards.
2. Shuffle fountain cards well and distribute 7 cards to each player. You should NOT show off your own cards to others.
3. Make a deck with remaining cards.
4. Gather all lucky tokens in one place.
5. Shuffle 15 round cards and select random 5 cards to build round deck. Only 5 chosen cards will be used in this game.
6. Show off the top card of round deck. Check the written number of token and place lucky tokens of that number next to round card.
7. Start the game. The person who see fountain most recently is the first player.

There has ONLY 2 options! Play or Draw!
On your turn, there has 2 options.
Play the cards to earn points or Draw the cards to fill your hands. After that, your turn is over.

Action #1. Play the card(s). (Color match or Number match)
Play the card(s) of your hand on the board.
To do so, you must match color or number with current base card.
Every time you play a card, current base card will be replaced to the last card you play.
(In other words, base card will be changed every time you play a card.)
You can play card again and again if color or number is same with replaced base card. Regardless of sign, number is matter. (‘-4’ and ‘4’ are ‘number matched’ in this game.)
You cannot play cards on multiple area. You can only play ONE sequence of cards.

Point!
Current base card changes every time someone plays a card to last played card. You can play cards again and again if color or number is matched.
Because starting cards is ‘7’ and there has no ‘7’ in fountain cards, the first play must be ‘color match’.

Action #2. Draw the cards. (Draw 2 cards from deck)
You don’t want to or can’t play card(s), draw 2 cards form deck to hand.
All player can hold cards up to 7. If you are holding more cards, discard any card(s) to make 7 cards in your hand. Discarded card(s) will not be used in this game.

To get ‘Lucky Token’…!?
Round card shows 2 information, ‘Lucky number’ and ‘Lucky token’. ‘Lucky number’ is goal of this round.
‘Lucky token’ is reward of this round.
After player finishes card playing, add all number from base card to last card. If result is same with ‘lucky number’ of this round, that player can earn ‘lucky token’ per each card that he (or she) plays.
Even though player plays more cards than remaining token, player can earn remaining ‘lucky token’ only.
Before end of turn, put together all cards that player plays and put the last card on the top of pile to notice what is current base card.
When all ‘lucky token’ is distributed of this round, show off next top card of round deck and place written number of ‘lucky token’.

Point!
Strategically, play as many cards as possible to earn more and give as less earning chance as possible to others.

The end of game
When all ‘lucky token’ of 5 rounds is distributed, the game ends immediately.
If you are holding cards at the end of the game, that gives you a penalty.
Discard your ‘lucky token’ per each card you have.
Who has token most is the winner of this game.

Point!
You have to manage your fountain cards if you think end is coming!

name: Shiki
description: Become the Master of Haiku! Compete in the grand annual Haiku festival. Demonstrate your poetic mastery of imagery and form. Choose your words carefully.

name: If Mama Ain't Happy...: Pestilence Pack
description:
Dissatisfied with Her Progress in Eliminating the Human Race, Mother Nature Has Unleashed Every Illness Imaginable:
Acne, Gingivitis, Even Restless Leg Syndrome - Whatever It Takes!

—description from the designer

name: If Mama Ain't Happy...: Attack Pack
description:
Disasters Haven’t Worked, Diseases Didn’t Do It. Now Mother Nature Has Turned The Plants and Animals Against The Human Race. And They’re Out to Get Even!

—description from the publisher

name: Mutation Wars
description:
In Mutation Wars you and your opponents are competing to be the first to develop a creature that can rule the ocean depths!

All players begin with a tiny creature — one body (tile) and must build it up as the game is played. To do this, each turn all players receive new cards from three different decks. The cards are used in different phases of the turn. A turn plays as follows:


Cards are dealt to all players — one each from the Body Part, Mutate and Battle card decks
Build Phase — players can use their Body Part cards to add a body part to their creature or purchase a new body (tile) with Body Part cards
Mutate Phase — players can use their Mutate cards to change their creature, change their opponent's creatures or affect all creatures for the current turn
Battle Phase — players can attack other creatures in an attempt to steal their Mutate and Battle cards; players can use their Battle cards to help them increase their stats and thus their possibility of winning
Cleanup Phase — players can exchange three Mutate cards or three Battle cards for one Body Part card


The game is won when a player succeeds in having a winning creature survive until the end of a turn. A winning creature requires four bodies (tiles) and six body parts (cards attached to the tiles) and must also have a color-matching body part on each of the external bodies. Should multiple players create a winning creature in the same turn and have them survive to the end of the turn, whoever built it first is the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Modular Board, Paper-and-Pencil, Variable Player Powers

name: Wizards of War
description:
In Wizards of War you play an evil wizard and your goal is to defeat the other wizard by casting spells and summon monsters.

Each turn you roll the action die to see what you can do that turn. If you roll a staff you get a spell, if you roll an orc you get a monster (summoned directly and placed on the board) and if you roll the feet you can move your wizard / monsters and attack (or cast a spell if it's the wizard).

The battle takes place on a board (containing 11 x 20 squares) with terrain affecting movement and combat.

Fighting goes as follows: The attacker does damage based on the amount of swords that are rolled. The defender blocks damage based on the amount of shields that are rolled. The difference is then subtracted from the defender’s life total. The wizards has 4 lives, the monsters all have one. If the defender survives the attack he gets one counterattack.

—description from the designer

name: Ascent: The Himalayas
description:
Prepare to embark on an epic journey as you ascend the slopes of the Himalayan peaks. The objective is for you (or your team) to have scored the most points at the end of the game when the expedition reaches the Summit.

At each Altitude Level, you make a bid for the number of tricks you think you will take and your goal is to reach exactly that bid without going over or under. If you reach your bid, you receive points; otherwise, you lose points.

—description from the designer

name: Ark of Atlantis
description:
Introduction:

Ark of Atlantis is a worker placement style board game. During each turn, players work hard to collect resources, save creatures, and find artifacts all while trying to build a ship large enough to save all of their workers before Atlantis sinks. As players race against time and each other, Atlantis continues to sink around them. Players must juggle their time between building a ship to save themselves and risking everything in order to save all that Atlantis holds dear. Players receive bonus points for risking and saving precious items from around the island before they too are lost to the sea.


The Goal of the Game:

The goal of the game is to acquire more victory points than any other player. Players receive victory points for building ship sections, collecting treasure tokens, and selling resources. Players lose victory points for each worker they were unable to save at the end of the game.

How Ark of Atlantis Plays:
Players take turns placing their workers around the island. On a player’s turn they can collect resources, build ship sections, or save valuable creatures, treasures, potions, and rare books from around the island to gain extra victory points. Each time a player places a worker or a group of workers they must then move their time track marker forward for each worker they placed. In Ark of Atlantis, the turn order is constantly changing depending on where a player’s time track marker is positioned on the time track. If a player’s marker lands on or passes over an event space the player draws an event card and then resolves it by flipping over an island tile. The second time an island tile would be flipped it is removed from the game. The game ends once all island tiles have been removed. Next, players tally up their victory points by adding any bonus points or deducting points for each worker they were unable to save. The player with the most points wins the game.

-description from designer

name: Pick Your Brain
description:
Pick Your Brain is a family based trivia game consisting of 52 trivia cards with each card having 4 categories totaling 208 trivia questions in each deck, currently we have one deck available but I’ll be expanding in the near future. The game is designed for 2 or more players, we suggest ages 8 and up. The object of the game is to reach 100 points first. What’s in the box: 52 card deck, 5 pencils, 1 (30 second) timer, answer tablets, 1 rule sheet and score sheet.

GAME PLAY: at the beginning of the game a “game moderator” is picked and supplies are handed out to each player. The moderator picks a category card from the deck and chooses one of the 4 categories I.e. state nicknames. Once the moderator has told the players the category the moderator will announce begin, at that point the moderator will start the sand timer. Each player with a moderator approved correct answer will be awarded a point. First player to 100 points wins.

—description from the publisher

name: Jafabit
description:
Jafabit is a player elimination board-game designed for 2 or more players. It combines elements of Chess with resource gathering and dice rolling mechanics on a 3D hexagonal tile map. It gracefully balances strategy and luck.

Jafabit is simple to set up and learn! Everything is color-coded and just makes sense. Maps look like maps complete with mountains and valleys. Everyone has a set of Chess-Dice they use to gather resources and dominate the map. Combining polyhedral dice and Chess pieces is what really brings Jafabit to a new level.

Jafabit is modular, with countless possible game maps to play on. A typical game lasts between a half an hour and a full hour, but can go a little longer. Jafabit is designed for ages 10 and up.

Jafabit is more than just a game it’s a game system. There are numerous optional expansions already in the works. The first of these optional expansions is The Mists expansion and will be included in the initial release.

Layering new rules and pieces on top of Jafabit can result in an infinite world of possibilities - entirely new games with a simple and fun interface to tie them all together! The base mechanics just meld so nicely and are completely open to expansion.

—description from the designer
categories: Dice, Exploration, Farming, Print & Play, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Player Elimination

name: Anarcade 8-Bit Rummy
description:
Shuffle your way through classic gaming with Anarcade 8-Bit Rummy! Play a set of cards from your hand with matching lines or mix up existing sets to find the matches you need. Score by playing all your cards first and the first player with 8 points wins!

Anarcade 8-Bit Rummy is based on familiar rummy card game rules with a few twists. All cards have a number (1-8) in each of three rows (top, middle or bottom). The objective is to play cards from your hand by making sets of cards that have matching numbers in the same row. You can also play cards directly to extend existing sets or rearrange sets into new ones using cards from your hand. The winner of the round gets points for each of their opponents' remaining cards.

—description from the designer

name: Hyper Battle Kaiju Fight: Wave 1 Battle Pack
description:
Based on the original kaiju characters of game designer and manga artist Alex Strang, Hyper Battle Kaiju Fight is an action-packed (yet simple to play) monster-fighting game using large ‘Battlecards’.

Each player uses a Battlecard to represent their giant monster. The large-size illustrated card has all of the monster's abilities and strategic moves arranged on the back, using a unique tactical grid system for battling and tracking results.

Kaiju Battles can end in many ways, from total defeat (monster explode!), concession, running away, draws, and more.

Also: Circular Zone Cards represent various planets and other galactic environments that affect gameplay, and Bonus Cards provide surprising extra moves and events that can alter battles.

The game can be played with 2 players, and becomes even wild with multiple players.

Wave 1 Battlepacks include 4 rndomly selected Kaiju Battlecards, 3 random Zone cards, 2 random Bonus Cards and rules!

There are also collectible trading cards, manga and more, as part of this shared universe. Surreal science-fiction meets monstrous mayhem!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Pattern Recognition, Simulation

name: SEMPER FIDELIS: Reglamento multitemporal de batallas con figuras
description:
Multitemporal rules for battles with miniatures. It is a Spanish game already discontinued that allows you to play any historical scenario, fantasy or futuristic, at any scale, and with the possibility of creating units to your liking, and a simple conversion table of other games profiles to Semper Fidelis. HAs also rules to combine it with RPG games, and finish the adventure with final battle. The expansions are Fight and Conquest, Blood and Metal, and some novels. Was also the first miniatures game to include firefighters rules.

—description from the designer
categories: Book, Fantasy, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling

name: GaiaVora
description:
Objective:

On the barren Planet of Gaia, players are Nature Spirits creating lush verdant lands, and giving rise to Life-Forms which come in three Species: CarniVores, HerbiVores, and Plants. But the swollen Moon, Vora, gazes hungrily from the night sky. It is jealous of Gaia’s life, and influences Species to eat each other!

The objective of the game is for your Life-Forms to:


Eat the Life-Forms of your opponents,
Survive to the end of the game without being eaten or killed.
Stand on top of many layers of Tiles.


Gameplay:

Each turn, rotate the planet 2 steps. (Spend one of your three "Star Tokens" to rotate it 3 steps, or only 1 step. You never get any more Stars.) Whenever a Land Tile rotates to the position under the Moon, Eating occurs there: Herbivores eat Plants, and Carnivores eat Herbivores.

After rotating the Planet, choose one of the four corners of the board. The Sky Object printed there (Sun, Meteor, Rainbow, or Storm) will activate its ability on whichever location on the Planet has now been rotated beneath it. Life-forms are born under the Rainbow and the Sun, migrate out from under the Storm, and get blown up when the Meteor drops a Land Tile on them.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Meet the Manchers
description:
Meet the Manchers is a game in which each player is a family member from the Manchers family, who are about to have their traditional Sunday feast. Some families go to church, some families take picnics, the Manchers have their Sunday feast. Many dishes will be cooked, not everyone will try them all, because this is not a quiet family dinner oh no, it is more of a race filled with many flavors and nutrition accompanied with the occasional duel for table dominance. However, rules must still be obeyed, table manners are important, the nicest member will be praised and will get a reward, the naughtiest member will be scold and left to do the dishes. Eating tasty food is important, but more so are the flavors and nutrition. Will you be the one who will accomplish all three, or be stuck with dishes…

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Voting

name: MythMash
description:
MythMash is a worldbuilding and story generation game in which players draw prompts and improvise a vibrant narrative together. It's simple rules and sandbox style make it a versatile tool for planning character backstories, lore and questlines. It can also be used as a real time campaign aide, creative writing generator or improv. prompt tool!
—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Children's Game, City Building, Fantasy, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Acting, Modular Board, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Storytelling, Tile Placement

name: Archers of Godfrey
description:
An intense cooperative, dice-rolling, unique tower defense set in a medieval fantasy world for 1 to 4 players. Have you ever wanted to be an archer on a castle wall? Now is your chance because all players play as archers defending against four powerful armies all attacking at once. Will the small band of archers defend the great castle of Godfrey or will the four Captains of the armies gain control of the castle? It is up to you and your team of archers so, “Notch, Draw, Loose!”

How To Win:
Players win if all four Captains are killed before one reaches the Center of the Keep.

Players lose if:
>> A Captain reaches the Keep at the center of the Inner Court.
>> All ten soldiers of any one army are placed on their quadrant in the bailey.
>> The Player’s Deck has no more cards left to draw.

General Gameplay:
The goal of the game is to kill all 4 Captains before 1 advances to the Keep. Archers will be attacking the Captains with their arrows while eliminating the invading armies. Players will also use cards and purchase items from the Archer’s Equipment to accomplish this goal.

Every normal arrow is worth 1 damage unless otherwise stated on the cards or with special abilities. Each archer has 5 arrows and 5 spaces to move each turn.

The 12mm dice are the soldiers of the different armies that are invading the castle. The health of a soldier is determined by what it rolls. Archers can ONLY attack soldiers in their row of their quadrant. Archers kill soldiers with their arrows by reducing the soldier’s health down to 0. Archers receive an Archer Trophy for each soldier they kill during their turn. Archers will use these trophies to purchase equipment to help them defeat the Captains.

When a soldier's health reaches 0, then remove that dice from the bailey and place it back on its army’s card in the Gathering Area. The soldier dice will be rolled again and placed in a future round.

Archers do NOT receive an Archer Trophy if soldier dice are killed while being placed during the Enemy phase. However, Archers do earn trophies for soldier dice killed by barrels and cards that upgrade their arrows.

Most of the cards are split and have two options. Players choose one option to play and then discard. Players CANNOT play both of the options on the split cards. Split cards are designed to help for the different situations that players find themselves in.

Each round has two phases: Archer Phase and Enemy Phase.

Archer Phase
Each Archer Phase consists of all 4 archers taking their turns.

Player’s Turn:
Draw 1 Card
Add to hand or follow the instructions if it is an Enemy Card. “Captain Advance” cards advance the Captain to the next space in their trail toward the Keep at the center of the Inner Court.
“Extra Soldier” cards will add an additional soldier to be placed during the Enemy Phase of that round (

2) Anytime during an archer’s turn they may:
Move 5 spaces and Shoot 5 arrows.
Play 1 card from your hand OR purchase items from the Archer's Equipment
If you purchase items, then you CANNOT play a card in the same turn.
If you play a card, then you CANNOT purchase items in the same turn.

3) Discard for hand limit
4) Pass the 1st player Castle Token to the person on your left (Clockwise)

Player’s Movement:
Archers are allowed to move to any space along the castle walls with a yellow border. Only one archer is allowed on each space along the wall. However, two archers may be on a “Starting Position” at the same time while they are moving along the wall. And as archers move past another archer, they CANNOT shoot arrows in the row of the other archer as they pass over them.

Stairs do not count as a space, the Archers just walk through them to the next space with a yellow border. Start positions do count as one space when the Archers are moving around to the other wall.

Enemy Phase
Each Enemy phase begins immediately following the Archer Phase.
The Enemy Phase consists of 3 elements:
Roll the d8 Captain dice and resolve.
Check what number you rolled with the Roman numerals on the 4 corner towers. Whatever number you rolled, the Captain in that quadrant advances one space.

If the Captain is in the bailey,then add a rolled soldier in the space that the Captain advanced from.

If the Captain is in the Inner Court, then resolve any Barricades that they might have passed through. No soldiers are ever placed in the Inner Court.

If that Captain is dead, then nothing happens. Take a deep breathe. You DO NOT re-roll if you rolled to advance a dead Captain.
Roll the Soldier Placement dice for each of the 4 armies and place 2 soldiers on to each quadrant of the bailey.

Roll 8 new soldiers (2 for each army) and place them on the two soldier positions of their army card. These will be placed in the next round during the Enemy Phase.
The highest health is placed in position #1
The lowest health is placed in position #2

After rolling the NEXT soldiers and placing them on their army cards, then the Archer Phase of the next round begins

name: Soulbound
description:
Paragon Studio's flagship game, Soulbound is a strategic battle card game experience unlike any other before it. Utilising the "everything in one box" model, everyone who plays Soulbound will be able to experience the game as it is intended to be, without the financial investment hurdle. Feel the thrill of commanding creatures of mythology to become the next Soulbound!

Along with creatures of mythology, Soulbound introduces a unique take on explaining what happened to these creatures that stoppped their existence in Modern Day planet Earth. Explore how the unknown war of the heavens and hell, known as "The Vanishing", caused Pandora's Box to thrust creatures of mythology and Gods alike into an alternate reality of planet Earth, known as Axiom07 by the greater beings. To the local population, the planet is called Duhra, and they have no idea about the darkness that they will have to fight back in order to survive.

Soulbound is the world's first battle card game that gives you the authentic Trading Card Game experience, while incorporating a heavy influence from Tactical Turn-Based Strategy Role-Playing games and a "Dynamic Resource" system. With Melee creatures, Ranged creatures and Support creatures, players will get to make new kinds of tactical decisions.

Every game of Soulbound comes with every card available. It also comes with two starter decks pre-configured so that players can learn that game before jumping in to the deck building aspect. In a box, 2 players can easily create two competitive decks. For the most competitive players, they may find they need a copy of the game for their own. With an abundance of available cards to build decks from, your ability to make the correct tactical decisions will be the biggest difference in a game. Skill should always determine the best player, not the player with the deepest pockets.

Soulbound is played over a series of turns in which you, an Animan of the planet Duhra, command creatures in battle against other Animan to work your way up to the title of "Soulbound" and be entrusted with fighting back the darkness that escaped from Pandora's Tome. Utilising your own Soul Energy, you begin your turn by building up your resource to Call creatures to the field. Creatures are able to act the turn they are played to the field which creates a very high tempo game. Having a strong offence is just as important as having a strong defence, as your resource also acts as your life force. Throughout a game, it can be attacked and fluctuates because of that. No linear resource growth here.

Through the many creatures' abilities and combat, players attempt to make tactical decisions to break through the opponent's defences and deal damage to the opponent's resource. A skillful players will be able to manage both their own resource and their opponent's resource to ensure they always can have the upper hand.

With outstanding table presence, outstanding art, and outstanding gameplay, Soulbound will keep you engaged and constantly creating new combos in your head. In the end, the only thing that matters is dealing 60 Soul Damage to your opponent and claiming your spot among the Soulbound.

—description from the publisher

name: TANKS: The Modern Age â French AMX-10P Tank Expansion
description:
The AMX-10P was designed to allow French infantry a powerful, protected ride into battle. Normally, its main weapon is a 20mm cannon that will easily shred light vehicles and helicopters. In addition the AMX-10P can become a threat to even the most armored opponent by mounting the MILAN Anti-Tank Guided Missile.

Plastic components.

Contents:
1 AMX-10P Tank
1 AMX-10P Tank Card
2 Hero Cards
2 Crew Cards
1 Upgrade Card
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: TANKS: The Modern Age â Swingfire Tank Expansion
description:
The Swingfire is widely used by the British Army when they have a requirement for a mobile Anti-Tank Guided Missile platform. It mates a pair of missile launchers in a specially designed structure on the back of the FV-432 Armored Personnel Carrier. The Swingfire missile is a more veteran system, but it is still capable of destroying enemy tanks, while remaining hidden from view.

Plastic components.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Wiz-Dom
description:
Wiz-Dom
Roleplaying Game and educational tool that combines a kid-friendly fantasy game with problem solving.

Wiz-Dom is playable as either a collaborative tabletop- or an online game, where players assume to roles of young wizards, who enter the School of Magic where they solve problems, pass tests, and earn valuable items so they can ultimately fight the monsters in the Cave of Secrets in d20-based RPG-style combat.

The spin is that the problems are based on school subjects, like math and history, so that while kids are playing the game, they’re also demonstrating their mastery of educational concepts.

—description from the publisher





Gameplay
1. Players choose their Heroes. There are 4 female and 4 male Heroes, each with their unique powers. Heroes are young witches and wizards, entering the School of Magic. A game session spans a semester of their life. Players get the Hero Card and the matching Item- and Spell Cards.

2. The Game Master (can be teacher, senior student, parent, etc.) assembles the Deck of Exercises. There are cards of 3 difficulty levels: Easy, Medium and Hard and a certain number must be selected from each category. Subjects include Math, History, Science and general Trivia, with curricula that matches education from age of 10 to 16.

3. The Game Master selects (or randomly draws) a Boss Monster for the game session. All other game components (Cards, tiles, tokens, sheets, etc.) are placed near the gameboard.

4. Players can move on the board by either rolling 2s6 (random mode) or use Movement Cards, giving a more strategic angle to the game. As players move on the board (from Field 1 to Field 30), the following steps will happen:

Depending on the Field they landed on, they either draw a single Exercise Card matching the symbol on the field (Easy, Medium, Hard), or a Fortune Card for every player.

(a) If it was an Exercise Card, they get 3, 5 or 10 minutes to solve the Easy, Medium or Hard problems. They can use pen and paper, they can talk to each other - they can even ask for help from the Game Master. If they successfully solved the problem, they get rewards. Every player who successfully solved her exercise will get Rune Golds. If at least one player solved it correctly, they get Team Rune Golds. Red (Hard) cards yield Magic Items as well.

Also, every player with a successful solution can place a Dungeon Tile. Tiles will form the combat grid for the final battle. There are symbols on the tiles indicating that the player can draw an extra Spell or Item card when placing that Tile. And certain Tiles will summon monsters for the final battle.

(b) If it was a Fortune Card, each player gets one and resolve the effect immediately. There are supporting ones (gain bonuses, draw items, etc) and there are negative ones (lose bonuses, get cursed, etc).

5. The three corners on the Board (Classroom, Club and Magic Rental) are places where the team must stop, even if they would overstep it.

(a) Classroom: they can select an Exercise Card of any difficulty to solve
(b) Club: they can either play a minigame (not included in the box, choose anything you like to distract players for a bit), or have a little break
(c) Magic Rental: after completing the mandatory Red Exercise on Field 30, players can spend their Rune Golds on Items and Spell. They are more than encouraged to collaborate and communicate, to figure out some kind of strategy before entering the final combat. The identity of the Boss Monster is revealed at this point.

6. Once they are well equipped, it's time for the Final Battle! Heroes descend to the Dungeons to defend the school from attacking monsters! Final Battle is a turn-based combat using cards and a d20 dice.

Heroes and Monsters take their turn, with the order depending on their Movement value. Monsters are controlled by the Game Master, following the behaviour detailed on the corresponding combat sheet.

(a) Movement: a figure can make a number of steps equal to its Movement value. It can step in any direction on the Grid, it can even overstep friendly figures, but cannot cross walls or hostile squares.

(b) Use Card: after or before the Movement is completed, Heroes can use a single card each turn. It can be a spell (usually turned face down after use), or a weapon (can be used any number of times in a combat). Ranged attacks must consider line-of-sight with walls and other objects blocking the way.

Combat lasts until the last survivor, with Heroes getting extra Rune Golds as loot. They can use this during their next game session.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Role Playing

name: World of Mythology: Godolympics
description:
World of Mythology: Godolympics is a compact, competitive, highly adaptive and fast-paced mythological card game for 2-5 players.
Take tricks by playing Gods from five pantheons. Use their powers to get a tactical advantage. Hunt down the Gods of one mythology shown in your secret Diplomacy card. Adapt fast and gain as many bonuses as possible. Outrun your opponents on the racing track and become the Godolympics champion.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Mythology, Party Game, Racing
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Take That, Trick-taking

name: PROPAGANDA
description:
The purpose of the game is to permanently establish an ideology in the world, so it can flourish and, in time, become the dominant rule. There can be between 2-4 different ideologies competing to rule 12 Regions (plus one passive player too, The Anarchist). You expand your ideology by using Propaganda Cards to convert other people to your rule. The goal is to generate enough income to buy Strongholds. In return you will get Donations from loyal subjects with each passing round, to further promote your ideology. The first player who holds 3 Strongholds for 1 entire round wins the game.

The different ideologies are:

The Dictator (Autocracy)
The Capitalist (Democracy)
The Communist (Totalitarian)
The Fundamentalist (Theocracy)
The Anarchist (passive player)

name: Kingslayer
description:
A fast-paced and easy to learn competitive wargame for 2-4 players. Players manage an economy of resources and play event cards in order to build and expand an empire and destroy their opponents. There is only one winner in every game of Kingslayer, but there are three paths to victory: slay an opposing king, control 20 territories, or control the most territories when the deck of event cards runs out. Kingslayer, at it's core, is an exercise in resource management.

Players will spend their resources to send their units into unclaimed territories and to build settlements. Each territory may contain one settlement and for every settlement built players can add a resource to the resource pool. Players may use their new resources to continue to move units, build settlements, or attack opposing units. Players may also spend their resources on recruiting new units, which may only be placed on the same territory as their king, which can not move. Combat is decided through dice rolls and favors outnumbering your opponent as well as the attacker.

Kingslayer uses a unique turn order mechanic which moves in a clockwise order, but only for players with at least one resource currently in the resource pool. If a player doesn't have any resources in the resource pool, their turn is skipped. If no resources of any color are in the resource pool, the pool is refreshed and all players draw a card. As long as players have at least one resource in the resource pool, they may play one card on their turn instead of spending resources.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Take That, Variable Phase Order

name: Crypto When Lambo
description:
In this game, not only you can build a crypto empire, but also you can try to manipulate the market to gain advantage for your own coin or invest and trade your opponents’ coins to benefit from their success or failures.

Crypto When Lambo (CWL) board game was inspired by crypto fortunes that were made and lost overnight. Your goal is to build a crypto empire with your own crypto company and coin to become the most successful crypto investor.

The game takes place across the 8 cities of the world that contain 64 resource producing city tiles. You begin the game with 3 offices, 2 crypto company share cards (each representing 1 million coins), and 5 million game currency. The first player to reach 1 billion or 50 Winning Point Count (WPC) wins the game.

To gain WPCs, you must increase the number of your employees, build products, open new offices, complete your management team, ICO your coin, and list it on crypto exchanges. There are 5 resource types (Real Estate, Employee, Management Team, Product, and Crypto Exchange) in the game that allow you to perform various actions to gain points and make money. For example, using 2 Real Estate cards and paying 2 million, you can establish a new office. Each office placed on the board is 2 WPCs and each Product you produce is worth 2 WPCs. There are multiple paths to getting additional points such as by becoming the richest person in the crypto world or leading a crypto company to ICO with several products and employees dominating the markets.

How do you acquire these resources? It’s very simple. Each turn a player rolls the dice and the total determines which city production centers will produce resources. Different cities have different attributes. For example, New York and London have more management talent but real estate is harder to get. Hong Kong has a lot of employees that can be recruited. New York is highly regulated and harder to have Crypto Exchanges whereas Tokyo and Hong Kong have more Crypto Exchanges that are accessible.

How do you earn money? For example, 1 Product card can be traded for 5 million. Other resource cards can be traded for 1 million. You can also trade your resources with other players during your turn. You can also do Crypto Trading during your turn and risk some of your money for potential high reward. You can also make money by buying low and selling high your opponents’ coins by manipulating the market with CWL Action Cards.

In CWL, your most important asset is your crypto company shares. You start the game with 2 of 10 company share cards, each representing 1 million coins. In the beginning of the game your coins have zero value. This is tracked by the Coin Price ticker cards you have in front of you always visible to all players. You must try to acquire as many as your company share cards as you can while they have zero value. You can also acquire other players’ share cards before they go ICO to benefit from their ICO price hype. Picking the right time for ICO will determine the revenue you will get from your ICO. Number of products, employees, management team, and manipulation of markets will all affect the coin price. You should try to increase your coin price as high as possible before launching your ICO while trying to manipulate your opponents’ coin prices. This is all done by using combination of resource cards.

In order to ICO, a player has to own at least 5 company share cards, a Board of Directors Management card, one of the C-level management cards (CEO, CFO, CIO or CISO) and at least one Employee card. One well timed successful ICO could take you from several million to well above 500 million. ICO is worth 10 WPCs.

There is a strategy involved around placement of Offices on the board in the beginning of the game to trading and manipulation of coin prices to timing of the ICO to raise money. Every game develops differently due to actions of each player.

CWL is full of fun with trading, resource management, market manipulation, and teaming concepts. It is simple to learn but hard to master with all the strategies available to you.

Get ready for your first adventure on CWL. Have fun building your Crypto Empire!

-description from designer
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Stock Holding

name: Gear Up: a puzzling game for gearheads
description:
Gear Up is a highly replayable pattern recognition card game (for all ages) having similar merits of dominoes & jigsaw puzzles. A take-along game that can be played by individuals or in teams, casually or as a timed challenge. Gear Up can be played as a solitaire-like activity by individuals who enjoy forming the most possible gears.

—description from the designer

name: Illegal Pyramid Scheme
description:
The fantasy of becoming filthy rich by building a pyramid scheme is now a fun family game. The outcome is known only at the very end. Rules are simple, and the game is unpredictable. There is no bankruptcy, and you are in the game until the money is counted when the game is over. Each player develops and controls schemes to make as much money as possible. The get-rich schemes is completely illegal in all civilized societies, including all 50 states of the USA. We produce this game so that you can use the power of the pyramid to make that incredible fortune.
—description from the publisher

Includes a free game called "Annexaton" in the same box.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Stock Holding, Tile Placement

name: Ultimate Ruler
description:
Theme:
The year is 1560, the year a prophecy claims one ruler will defeat all others and forever hold the throne. Do you have the mastery to build your army, defeat your foes, and prove that you are destined to be the Ultimate Ruler?

Choose your actions wisely as your fate, and that of the throne, is on the line.

---
Play:
All players start with an equal quantity of soldiers. On each turn players draw one Decree card and either play or discard one Decree Card (to draw another). Some cards played modify these actions, allowing additional draws or plays.

Other Decree cards allow players to Bribe, Recruit and cause Battle between their, their opponent, and the Neutral Soldiers. Cards change in power as the game progresses, so make your choices wisely. Strategy Hand-management is key for success in this game.

A great game for on-the-go fun with rapid, card-only play that's easy to learn but hard to master. Strategy evolves as the game progresses and power shifts between you, your enemies, and neutral.

—description from the designer

name: Stratopoly
description:
Yet another clone of Monopoly but with 144 cases, 24 series and many mechanics to influence your movement. Consequently, the game becomes a lot more strategic.

Main features:
All series are distributed at the beginning among the players
Players can use special cards to advance faster or slower, foward or backward.
Special cases or cards also allow players to move around the board strategically.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Semper Fidelis Alliance
description:
Game of battles with miniatures. Quick and easy rules to play immediately. The game comes with a book with the basic rules and lists of fighters. It is proposed as a cooperative game, in which different players (or only one) face an automated and undaunted enemy that does not know surrender.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Tragedy Looper: Young Girl
description:
A promotional card available in the 4th Issue of "Game Jamboree"
Depicts "Young Girl", or 'å¥³ã®å­' (Onnanoko)

Paranoia Limit: 1
Tags: girl, student
Starting Location: School
Passive: This character cannot move to the Shrine, City or Hospital
Goodwill Abilities:
1: This character's location restriction is removed
3: (1xL) Move this character to an adjacent location
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Murder/Mystery
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Memory, Team-Based Game

name: Silver City-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF SILVER CITY, NEW MEXICO? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Silver City we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, family attractions, and of course... world-renowned ancient cliff dwellings - a little something for every Silver City citizen! Looking for a fun way to experience the town that snard Bill the Kid?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite SIlver City properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO SILVER CITY! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many New Mexico Enchiladas from the Jalisco Cafe! THIS IS SILVER CITY... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: FlipFlick
description:
In FlipFlick, players will take on the role of a pancake chef as they prepare different beautiful pancake variations and yummy all-time favourites.

While cooking, the chefs will take actions and collect points for the pancakes they successfully flip. Players will make a choice of how much risk they are going to take in flipping the pancakes by flicking one, two or three pancake cards with their fingers and catching them again. Different markers on the cards indicate different levels of risk. The higher the risk, the more difficult the flip, the more points to win – and to lose, of course.

As competing chefs, players will have to interfere with their fellow co-chefs’ pancake flips and also steal their nicest creations to their advantage.

The player with the right combination of pancakes and the highest points wins.

-description from artist
categories: Action / Dexterity, Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Pattern Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Trick-taking

name: Survive The Night: The Party Board Game
description:
Choose from one of eight different characters to begin your story. Your character has a goal they are trying to accomplish.

If you don’t find your win card, you can still beat the game by being the first one to make it home to your bed without being arrested or drugged. Easy, right?

Start with beers at the brewery, dance on tables at Logan’s club and finish the night by trying not to get kicked out of the dive bar.

Playing the game is easy to learn and simple enough for a party environment. No long, boring rule book needed. Pick up a card. Do what it says!

—description from the designer

name: Sea Skirmish
description:
Sea Skirmish is a pocket size micro-war game. Its main mechanics involve point to point movement, action programming, and attacking other players through dice rolls.

The main playing pieces are cards that represent boats. These boats set sail among any table that represents the sea. There are no guidelines for table size. In fact the game encourages the use of different tables and use of various everyday objects that can act as obstacles for the boats to navigate between.

—user summary
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: True-Score Baseball
